(disambiguation)](/wiki/Finland_\(disambiguation\) "Finland
\(disambiguation\)").

**Finland** ([/ˈfɪnlənd/](/wiki/Help:IPA/English "Help:IPA/English") ([![About
this
sound](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/8/8a/Loudspeaker.svg/11px-
Loudspeaker.svg.png)](/wiki/File:En-us-Finland.ogg "About this sound")
[listen](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/b/b3/En-us-Finland.ogg "En-
us-Finland.ogg")); [Finnish](/wiki/Finnish_language "Finnish language"):
_Suomi_ [[suo̯mi]](/wiki/Help:IPA/Estonian_and_Finnish "Help:IPA/Estonian and
Finnish") ([![About this
sound](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/8/8a/Loudspeaker.svg/11px-
Loudspeaker.svg.png)](/wiki/File:Suomi_Finland.ogg "About this sound")
[listen](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/e/ed/Suomi_Finland.ogg
"Suomi Finland.ogg")); [Swedish](/wiki/Swedish_language "Swedish language"):
_Finland_ [[ˈfɪnland]](/wiki/Help:IPA/Swedish "Help:IPA/Swedish")), officially
the **Republic of Finland** ([Finnish](/wiki/Finnish_language "Finnish
language"): _Suomen tasavalta_ , [Swedish](/wiki/Swedish_language "Swedish
language"): _Republiken Finland_),[7] is a [sovereign
state](/wiki/Sovereign_state "Sovereign state") in [Northern
Europe](/wiki/Northern_Europe "Northern Europe"). The country has land borders
with [Sweden](/wiki/Sweden "Sweden") to the northwest, [Norway](/wiki/Norway
"Norway") to the north, and [Russia](/wiki/Russia "Russia") to the east. To
the south is the [Gulf of Finland](/wiki/Gulf_of_Finland "Gulf of Finland")
with [Estonia](/wiki/Estonia "Estonia") on the opposite side. Finland is a
[Nordic country](/wiki/Nordic_countries "Nordic countries") situated in the
geographical region of [Fennoscandia](/wiki/Fennoscandia "Fennoscandia"),
which also includes [Scandinavia](/wiki/Scandinavia "Scandinavia").

Finland's population is 5.5 million (2016), and the majority of the population
is concentrated in the southern region.[8] 88.7% of the population is
[Finnish](/wiki/Finns "Finns") and speaks [Finnish](/wiki/Finnish_language
"Finnish language"), a [Uralic language](/wiki/Uralic_languages "Uralic
languages") unrelated to the Scandinavian languages; the next group is the
[Finland-Swedes](/wiki/Swedish-speaking_population_of_Finland "Swedish-
speaking population of Finland") (5.3%). Finland is the [eighth largest
country in Europe](/wiki/Area_and_population_of_European_countries "Area and
population of European countries") and the most [sparsely
populated](/wiki/List_of_countries_and_territories_by_population_density "List
of countries and territories by population density") country in the [European
Union](/wiki/European_Union "European Union"). It is a
[parliamentary](/wiki/Parliamentary_system "Parliamentary system") republic
with a central government based in the capital city of
[Helsinki](/wiki/Helsinki "Helsinki"), local governments in 311
[municipalities](/wiki/Municipalities_of_Finland "Municipalities of
Finland"),[9] and one [autonomous region](/wiki/Autonomous_area "Autonomous
area"), the [Åland Islands](/wiki/%C3%85land_Islands "Åland Islands"). Over
1.4 million people live in the [Greater Helsinki](/wiki/Greater_Helsinki
"Greater Helsinki") metropolitan area, which produces one third of the
country's [GDP](/wiki/Gross_domestic_product "Gross domestic product").

Finland was inhabited when the last [ice age](/wiki/Ice_age "Ice age") ended,
approximately 9000 BCE.[10] The first settlers left behind artifacts that
present characteristics shared with those found in Estonia, Russia, and
Norway.[11] The earliest people were [hunter-gatherers](/wiki/Hunter-gatherer
"Hunter-gatherer"), using stone tools.[12] The first pottery appeared in 5200
BCE, when the [Comb Ceramic culture](/wiki/Pit%E2%80%93Comb_Ware_culture
"Pit–Comb Ware culture") was introduced.[13] The arrival of the [Corded Ware
culture](/wiki/Corded_Ware_culture "Corded Ware culture") in southern coastal
Finland between 3000 and 2500 BCE may have coincided with the start of
agriculture.[14] The [Bronze Age](/wiki/Bronze_Age "Bronze Age") and [Iron
Age](/wiki/Iron_Age "Iron Age") were characterised by extensive contacts with
other cultures in the [Fennoscandian](/wiki/Fennoscandia "Fennoscandia") and
[Baltic regions](/wiki/Baltic_region "Baltic region") and the sedentary
farming inhabitation increased towards the end of [Iron Age](/wiki/Iron_Age
"Iron Age"). At the time Finland had three main cultural areas, [Finland
proper](/wiki/Southwest_Finland "Southwest Finland"),
[Tavastia](/wiki/Tavastia_\(historical_province\) "Tavastia \(historical
province\)") and [Karelia](/wiki/Karelia_\(historical_province_of_Finland\)
"Karelia \(historical province of Finland\)"), which is reflected in e.g.
contemporary jewellery.[15]

From the late 13th century, Finland gradually became an integral part of
[Sweden](/wiki/Sweden "Sweden") through the [crusades](/wiki/Northern_Crusades
"Northern Crusades") and the Swedish part-colonisation of coastal Finland, a
legacy reflected in the prevalence of the Swedish language and its official
status. In 1809 Finland was incorporated into the [Russian
Empire](/wiki/Russian_Empire "Russian Empire") as the autonomous [Grand Duchy
of Finland](/wiki/Grand_Duchy_of_Finland "Grand Duchy of Finland"). In 1906,
Finland became the first European state to grant all adult citizens the right
to vote, and the first in the world to give all adult citizens the right to
run for public office.[16][17]

Following the 1917 [Russian Revolution](/wiki/Russian_Revolution "Russian
Revolution"), Finland declared itself independent. In 1918, the fledgling
state was divided by [civil war](/wiki/Finnish_Civil_War "Finnish Civil War"),
with the Bolshevik-leaning [Red
Guard](/wiki/Finnish_Socialist_Workers%27_Republic "Finnish Socialist Workers'
Republic") supported by the equally new [Soviet
Russia](/wiki/Russian_Soviet_Federative_Socialist_Republic "Russian Soviet
Federative Socialist Republic"), fighting the [White
Guard](/wiki/Whites_\(Finland\) "Whites \(Finland\)"), supported by the
[German Empire](/wiki/German_Empire "German Empire"). After a brief attempt to
[establish a kingdom](/wiki/Kingdom_of_Finland_\(1918\) "Kingdom of Finland
\(1918\)"), the country became a republic. During [World War
II](/wiki/World_War_II "World War II"), the Soviet Union sought repeatedly to
occupy Finland, with Finland losing parts of [Karelia](/wiki/Karelia
"Karelia"), [Salla](/wiki/Salla "Salla"), [Kuusamo](/wiki/Kuusamo "Kuusamo"),
[Petsamo](/wiki/Petsamo_Province "Petsamo Province") and some islands, but
retaining independence.

Finland joined the [United Nations](/wiki/United_Nations "United Nations") in
1955 and established an official policy of neutrality. The [Finno-Soviet
Treaty of 1948](/wiki/Finno-Soviet_Treaty_of_1948 "Finno-Soviet Treaty of
1948") gave the Soviet Union some leverage in Finnish domestic politics during
the [Cold War](/wiki/Cold_War "Cold War") era. Finland joined the
[OECD](/wiki/OECD "OECD") in 1969, the [NATO Partnership for
Peace](/wiki/Partnership_for_Peace "Partnership for Peace") in 1994,[18] the
[European Union](/wiki/European_Union "European Union") in 1995, the [Euro-
Atlantic Partnership Council](/wiki/Euro-Atlantic_Partnership_Council "Euro-
Atlantic Partnership Council") in 1997,[18] and finally the
[Eurozone](/wiki/Eurozone "Eurozone") at its inception, in 1999.

Finland was a relative latecomer to industrialisation, remaining a largely
[agrarian](/wiki/Agriculture "Agriculture") country until the 1950s. After
[World War II](/wiki/World_War_II "World War II"), the Soviet Union demanded
war reparations from Finland not only in money but also in material, such as
ships and machinery. This forced Finland to industrialise. It rapidly
developed an advanced economy while building an extensive [welfare
state](/wiki/Welfare_state "Welfare state") based on the [Nordic
model](/wiki/Nordic_model "Nordic model"), resulting in widespread prosperity
and one of the highest [per capita
incomes](/wiki/List_of_countries_by_GDP_\(nominal\)_per_capita "List of
countries by GDP \(nominal\) per capita") in the world.[19] However, Finnish
GDP growth was negative in 2012–2014 (−0.698% to −1.426%), with a preceding
nadir of −8% in 2009.[20]

Finland is a top performer in numerous metrics of national performance,
including education, economic competitiveness, civil liberties, quality of
life, and human development.[21][22][23][24] In 2015, Finland was ranked first
in the World Human Capital[25] and the [Press Freedom
Index](/wiki/Press_Freedom_Index "Press Freedom Index") and as the most stable
country in the world during 2011–2016 in the [Fragile States
Index](/wiki/Fragile_States_Index "Fragile States Index"),[26] and second in
the [Global Gender Gap Report](/wiki/Global_Gender_Gap_Report "Global Gender
Gap Report").[27] A large majority of Finns are members of the [Evangelical
Lutheran Church](/wiki/Evangelical_Lutheran_Church_of_Finland "Evangelical
Lutheran Church of Finland"),[28] and freedom of religion is guaranteed under
the [Finnish Constitution](/wiki/Constitution_of_Finland "Constitution of
Finland").

## Etymology[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Finland&action=edit&section=1 "Edit
section: Etymology")]

See also: [Finns § Etymology](/wiki/Finns#Etymology "Finns")

The first known written appearance of the name _Finland_ is thought to be on
three rune-stones. Two were found in the Swedish province of
[Uppland](/wiki/Uppland "Uppland") and have the inscription _finlonti_ ([U
582](/wiki/Runestone_U_582 "Runestone U 582")). The third was found in
[Gotland](/wiki/Gotland "Gotland"). It has the inscription _finlandi_ ([G
319](/wiki/Runestone_G_319 "Runestone G 319")) and dates back to the 13th
century.[29] The name can be assumed to be related to the tribe name _Finns_ ,
which is mentioned at first known time AD 98 (disputed meaning).

### Suomi[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Finland&action=edit&section=2 "Edit
section: Suomi")]

The name _Suomi_ ([Finnish](/wiki/Finnish_language "Finnish language") for
"Finland") has uncertain origins, but a candidate for a source is the Proto-
Baltic word _*źemē_ , meaning "land". In addition to the close relatives of
Finnish (the [Finnic languages](/wiki/Finnic_languages "Finnic languages")),
this name is also used in the [Baltic languages](/wiki/Baltic_languages
"Baltic languages") [Latvian](/wiki/Latvian_language "Latvian language") and
[Lithuanian](/wiki/Lithuanian_language "Lithuanian language"). Alternatively,
the Indo-European word *_gʰm-on_ "man" (cf. Gothic _guma_ , Latin _homo_) has
been suggested, being borrowed as *_ćoma_. The word originally referred only
to the province of [Finland
Proper](/wiki/Finland_Proper_\(historical_province\) "Finland Proper
\(historical province\)"), and later to the northern coast of [Gulf of
Finland](/wiki/Gulf_of_Finland "Gulf of Finland"), with northern regions such
as [Ostrobothnia](/wiki/Ostrobothnia_\(historical_province\) "Ostrobothnia
\(historical province\)") still sometimes being excluded until later. Earlier
theories suggested derivation from _suomaa_ ([fen](/wiki/Fen "Fen") land) or
_suoniemi_ (fen cape), and parallels between _saame_ ([Sami](/wiki/Sami_people
"Sami people"), a Finno-Ugric people in [Lapland](/wiki/Lapland_\(Finland\)
"Lapland \(Finland\)")), and _[Häme](/wiki/Tavastia_\(historical_province\)
"Tavastia \(historical province\)")_ (a province in the inland) were drawn,
but these theories are now considered outdated.[30]

### Concept[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Finland&action=edit&section=3 "Edit
section: Concept")]

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/c/c8/Hakkapeliitta-1940.jpg/170px-
Hakkapeliitta-1940.jpg)](/wiki/File:Hakkapeliitta-1940.jpg)

[](/wiki/File:Hakkapeliitta-1940.jpg "Enlarge")

[Hakkapeliitta](/wiki/Hakkapeliitta "Hakkapeliitta") featured on a 1940
Finnish stamp

In the earliest historical sources from the 12th and 13th centuries, the term
Finland refers to the coastal region around [Turku](/wiki/Turku "Turku") from
[Perniö](/wiki/Perni%C3%B6 "Perniö") to [Uusikaupunki](/wiki/Uusikaupunki
"Uusikaupunki"). This region later became known as Finland Proper in
distinction from the country name Finland. Finland became a common name for
the whole country in a centuries-long process that started when the [Catholic
Church](/wiki/Catholic_Church "Catholic Church") established missionary
diocese in [Nousiainen](/wiki/Nousiainen "Nousiainen") in the northern part of
the province of Suomi possibly sometime in the 12th century.[31]

In the 15th century, _Finland_ became a common name for the whole land area to
the east of the [Bothnian Sea](/wiki/Bothnian_Sea "Bothnian Sea"), possibly
even including the [Åland Islands](/wiki/%C3%85land_Islands "Åland Islands"),
when the archipelago was seen as belonging to Turku. What the term actually
refers to can vary depending on the sources. In addition, the boundaries to
the east and the north were not exact. An establishment of sorts of Finland as
a united entity, if only in name, was made when [John III of
Sweden](/wiki/John_III_of_Sweden "John III of Sweden") called his
[duchy](/wiki/Duchy "Duchy") the "Grand Duchy of Finland" (about 1580), as a
strategy to counter the claims of the Russian [tsar](/wiki/Tsar "Tsar"). The
term became part of the title of the [King of Sweden](/wiki/King_of_Sweden
"King of Sweden") but had little practical meaning. The Finnish land area had
the same standing as the area to the west of the Bothnian Sea, and the Finnish
part of the realm had the same representation in the parliament as the western
part. In 1637, Queen [Christina](/wiki/Christina,_Queen_of_Sweden "Christina,
Queen of Sweden") named [Per Brahe the Younger](/wiki/Per_Brahe_the_Younger
"Per Brahe the Younger") [Governor-General of Finland](/wiki/Governor-
General_of_Finland "Governor-General of Finland"), Åland, and
[Ostrobothnia](/wiki/Ostrobothnia_\(historical_province\) "Ostrobothnia
\(historical province\)") (other parts of Sweden had also had [governor
generals](/wiki/Governor_general "Governor general")).

The modern boundaries of Finland actually came into existence only after the
end of [Sweden–Finland](/wiki/Sweden%E2%80%93Finland "Sweden–Finland"). What
was signed over to Russia in 1809 was not so much "Finland" as six counties,
Åland, and a small part of [Västerbotten
County](/wiki/V%C3%A4sterbotten_County "Västerbotten County"). The boundary
between the new [Grand Duchy of Finland](/wiki/Grand_Duchy_of_Finland "Grand
Duchy of Finland") and the remaining part of Sweden could have been drawn
along the river [Kemijoki](/wiki/Kemijoki "Kemijoki"), the boundary at the
time between Västerbotten County and Österbotten County (Ostrobothnia) – as
proposed by the Swedes in the peace negotiations – or along the river
[Kalix](/wiki/Kalix_River "Kalix River"), thereby including the Finnish-
speaking part of [Meänmaa](/wiki/Me%C3%A4nmaa "Meänmaa") – as proposed by the
Russians. The actual boundary, which followed the [Torne
River](/wiki/Torne_River "Torne River") and the [Muonio
River](/wiki/Muonio_River "Muonio River") to the fells [Saana](/wiki/Saana
"Saana") and [Halti](/wiki/Halti "Halti") in the northwest, was a compromise.
The area it delineated was to become what was represented by the concept of
Finland – at least after Tsar [Alexander I of
Russia](/wiki/Alexander_I_of_Russia "Alexander I of Russia") permitted the
parts of Finland located to the east of the [Kymi River](/wiki/Kymi_River
"Kymi River"), which were conquered by Russia in 1721 and 1743, called "[Old
Finland](/wiki/Old_Finland "Old Finland")", to be administratively included in
"New Finland" in 1812.

## History[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Finland&action=edit&section=4 "Edit
section: History")]

Main article: [History of Finland](/wiki/History_of_Finland "History of
Finland")

### Prehistory[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Finland&action=edit&section=5 "Edit
section: Prehistory")]

Main article: [History of Finland §
Prehistory](/wiki/History_of_Finland#Prehistory "History of Finland")

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/e/e2/Northern_Europe_in_814.jpg/220px-
Northern_Europe_in_814.jpg)](/wiki/File:Northern_Europe_in_814.jpg)

[](/wiki/File:Northern_Europe_in_814.jpg "Enlarge")

Northern Europe in 814

According to [archaeological](/wiki/Archaeology "Archaeology") evidence, the
area now comprising Finland was settled at the latest around 8500 BCE during
the [Stone Age](/wiki/Stone_Age "Stone Age") as the ice sheet of the [last ice
age](/wiki/Last_glacial_period "Last glacial period") receded. The
[artifacts](/wiki/Artifact_\(archaeology\) "Artifact \(archaeology\)") the
first settlers left behind present characteristics that are shared with those
found in Estonia, Russia, and Norway.[11] The earliest people were [hunter-
gatherers](/wiki/Hunter-gatherer "Hunter-gatherer"), using stone tools.[12]
The first pottery appeared in 5200 BCE, when the Comb Ceramic culture was
introduced.[13] The arrival of the [Corded Ware
culture](/wiki/Corded_Ware_culture "Corded Ware culture") in southern coastal
Finland between 3000 and 2500 BCE may have coincided with the start of
agriculture.[14] Even with the introduction of agriculture, hunting and
fishing continued to be important parts of the subsistence economy.

The [Bronze Age](/wiki/Bronze_Age "Bronze Age") (1500–500 BCE) and [Iron
Age](/wiki/Iron_Age "Iron Age") (500 BCE–1200 CE) were characterised by
extensive contacts with other cultures in the
[Fennoscandian](/wiki/Fennoscandia "Fennoscandia") and [Baltic
regions](/wiki/Baltic_region "Baltic region"). There is no consensus on when
Uralic languages and [Indo-European languages](/wiki/Indo-European_languages
"Indo-European languages") were first spoken in the area of contemporary
Finland. During the first millennium AD, early Finnish was spoken in
agricultural settlements in southern Finland, whereas Sámi-speaking
populations occupied most parts of the country. Although distantly related,
the [Sami](/wiki/Sami_people "Sami people") are a different people that
retained the hunter-gatherer lifestyle longer than the Finns. The Sami
cultural identity and the [Sami language](/wiki/Sami_languages "Sami
languages") have survived in Lapland, the northernmost province, but the Sami
have been displaced or assimilated elsewhere.

The 12th and 13th centuries were a violent time in the northern Baltic sea.
The [Livonian crusade](/wiki/Livonian_Crusade "Livonian Crusade") was ongoing
and Finnish tribes such as the [Tavastians](/wiki/Tavastians "Tavastians") and
[Karelians](/wiki/Karelia_\(historical_province_of_Finland\) "Karelia
\(historical province of Finland\)") were in [frequent
conflicts](/wiki/Early_Finnish_wars "Early Finnish wars") with
[Novgorod](/wiki/Republic_of_Novgorod "Republic of Novgorod") and with each
other. Also during the 12th and 13th centuries several crusades from the
Catholic realms of the Baltic Sea were made against Finnish tribes. According
to historical sources, [Danes](/wiki/Danes "Danes") made two crusades to
Finland, in 1191 and in 1202,[32] and [Swedes](/wiki/Swedes "Swedes"),
possibly the so-called [second crusade to
Finland](/wiki/Second_Swedish_Crusade "Second Swedish Crusade"), in 1249
against [Tavastians](/wiki/Tavastians "Tavastians") and the [third crusade to
Finland](/wiki/Third_Swedish_Crusade "Third Swedish Crusade") in 1293 against
the [Karelians](/wiki/Karelia_\(historical_province_of_Finland\) "Karelia
\(historical province of Finland\)"). The so-called [first crusade to
Finland](/wiki/First_Swedish_Crusade "First Swedish Crusade"), possibly in
1155, is most likely an unreal event. Also it is possible that Germans made
violent conversion of Finnish pagans in 13th century.[33] According to a papal
letter in 1241 the king of Norway was also fighting against "nearby pagans" at
that time.[34]

### Swedish era[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Finland&action=edit&section=6 "Edit
section: Swedish era")]

Main article: [Finland under Swedish rule](/wiki/Finland_under_Swedish_rule
"Finland under Swedish rule")

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/2/28/Swedish_Empire_%281560-1815%29_en2.png/220px-
Swedish_Empire_%281560-1815%29_en2.png)](/wiki/File:Swedish_Empire_\(1560-1815\)_en2.png)

[](/wiki/File:Swedish_Empire_\(1560-1815\)_en2.png "Enlarge")

The [Swedish Empire](/wiki/Swedish_Empire "Swedish Empire") following the
[Treaty of Roskilde](/wiki/Treaty_of_Roskilde "Treaty of Roskilde") of 1658.  
Dark green: [Sweden proper](/wiki/Sweden_proper "Sweden proper"), as
represented in the [Riksdag of the Estates](/wiki/Riksdag_of_the_Estates
"Riksdag of the Estates"). Other greens: [Swedish
dominions](/wiki/Dominions_of_Sweden "Dominions of Sweden") and
[possessions](/wiki/Possessions_of_Sweden "Possessions of Sweden").

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/d/da/Suomenlinna.jpg/220px-
Suomenlinna.jpg)](/wiki/File:Suomenlinna.jpg)

[](/wiki/File:Suomenlinna.jpg "Enlarge")

Now lying within Helsinki, [Suomenlinna](/wiki/Suomenlinna "Suomenlinna") is a
[UNESCO](/wiki/UNESCO "UNESCO") [World Heritage
Site](/wiki/World_Heritage_Site "World Heritage Site") consisting of an
inhabited 18th century sea fortress built on six islands. It is one of
Finland's most popular tourist attractions.

As a result of the crusades together and with the colonisation of Finnish
coastal areas with Christian [Swedish population](/wiki/Swedish-
speaking_population_of_Finland "Swedish-speaking population of Finland")
during the Middle Ages[35] Finland gradually became part of the kingdom of
Sweden.

In the 17th century, [Swedish](/wiki/Finland_Swedish "Finland Swedish") became
the dominant language of the nobility, administration, and education;
[Finnish](/wiki/Finnish_language "Finnish language") was chiefly a language
for the [peasantry](/wiki/Peasant "Peasant"), clergy, and local
[courts](/wiki/Court "Court") in predominantly Finnish-speaking areas.

During the [Protestant Reformation](/wiki/Protestant_Reformation "Protestant
Reformation"), the [Finns](/wiki/Finns "Finns") gradually converted to
[Lutheranism](/wiki/Lutheranism "Lutheranism").[36] In the 16th century,
[Mikael Agricola](/wiki/Mikael_Agricola "Mikael Agricola") published the first
written works in Finnish. The first university in Finland, the [Royal Academy
of Turku](/wiki/Royal_Academy_of_Turku "Royal Academy of Turku"), was
established in 1640. Finland suffered a severe [famine in
1696–1697](/wiki/Great_Famine_of_Finland_\(1695%E2%80%931697\) "Great Famine
of Finland \(1695–1697\)"), during which about one third of the Finnish
population died,[37] and a [devastating plague a few years
later](/wiki/The_plague_during_the_Great_Northern_War "The plague during the
Great Northern War"). In the 18th century, wars between Sweden and Russia
twice led to the occupation of Finland by Russian forces, times known to the
Finns as the [Greater Wrath](/wiki/Greater_Wrath "Greater Wrath") (1714–1721)
and the [Lesser Wrath](/wiki/Russo-Swedish_War_\(1741%E2%80%931743\) "Russo-
Swedish War \(1741–1743\)") (1742–1743).[37] It is estimated that almost an
entire generation of young men was lost during the Great Wrath, due namely to
the destruction of homes and farms, and to the burning of
[Helsinki](/wiki/Helsinki "Helsinki").[38] By this time Finland was the
predominant term for the whole area from the [Gulf of
Bothnia](/wiki/Gulf_of_Bothnia "Gulf of Bothnia") to the Russian border.

Two Russo-Swedish wars in twenty-five years served as reminders to the Finnish
people of the precarious position between Sweden and Russia. An increasingly
vocal elite in Finland soon determined that Finnish ties with Sweden were
becoming too costly, and following [Gustav III's War](/wiki/Russo-
Swedish_War_\(1788%E2%80%931790\) "Russo-Swedish War \(1788–1790\)")
(1788–1790), the Finnish elite's desire to break with Sweden only
heightened.[39]

In the late eighteenth century a politically active portion of the Finnish
nobility became convinced that, due to Sweden and Russia's repeated use of
Finland as a battlefield, it would be in the country's best interests to seek
autonomy. Even before the Russo-Swedish War of 1788–1790, there were
conspiring Finns, among them [Col G. M.
Sprengtporten](/wiki/Georg_Magnus_Sprengtporten "Georg Magnus Sprengtporten"),
who had supported [Gustav III's coup in
1772](/wiki/Gustav_III_of_Sweden#Coup_d'état "Gustav III of Sweden").
Sprengporten fell out with the king and resigned his commission in 1777. In
the following decade he tried to secure Russian support for an autonomous
Finland, and later became an adviser to Catherine II.[39] In the spirit of the
notion of [Adolf Ivar Arwidsson](/wiki/Adolf_Ivar_Arwidsson "Adolf Ivar
Arwidsson") (1791–1858), "we are not Swedes, we do not want to become
Russians, let us therefore be Finns", the Finnish national identity started to
become established.

Notwithstanding the efforts of Finland's elite and nobility to break ties with
Sweden, there was no genuine independence movement in Finland until the early
twentieth century. As a matter of fact, at this time the Finnish peasantry was
outraged by the actions of their elite and almost exclusively supported
Gustav's actions against the conspirators. (The High Court of Turku condemned
Sprengtporten as a traitor c. 1793.)[39]

### Russian Empire era[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Finland&action=edit&section=7
"Edit section: Russian Empire era")]

Main article: [Grand Duchy of Finland](/wiki/Grand_Duchy_of_Finland "Grand
Duchy of Finland")

See also: [Finland's language strife](/wiki/Finland%27s_language_strife
"Finland's language strife") and [Russification of
Finland](/wiki/Russification_of_Finland "Russification of Finland")

On 29 March 1809, having been taken over by the armies of [Alexander I of
Russia](/wiki/Alexander_I_of_Russia "Alexander I of Russia") in the [Finnish
War](/wiki/Finnish_War "Finnish War"), Finland became an autonomous [Grand
Duchy](/wiki/Grand_Duchy_of_Finland "Grand Duchy of Finland") in the [Russian
Empire](/wiki/Russian_Empire "Russian Empire") until the end of 1917. In 1811,
Alexander I incorporated Russian [Vyborg province](/wiki/Vyborg_Governorate
"Vyborg Governorate") into the Grand Duchy of Finland. During the Russian era,
the Finnish language began to gain recognition. From the 1860s onwards, a
strong Finnish [nationalist movement](/wiki/Ethnic_nationalism "Ethnic
nationalism") known as the [Fennoman movement](/wiki/Fennoman_movement
"Fennoman movement") grew. Milestones included the publication of what would
become Finland's [national epic](/wiki/National_epic "National epic") – the
_[Kalevala](/wiki/Kalevala "Kalevala")_ – in 1835, and the Finnish language's
achieving equal legal status with Swedish in 1892.

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/1/18/Pekka_Halonen_-
_Tienraivaajia_Karjalassa.jpg/220px-Pekka_Halonen_-
_Tienraivaajia_Karjalassa.jpg)](/wiki/File:Pekka_Halonen_-
_Tienraivaajia_Karjalassa.jpg)

[](/wiki/File:Pekka_Halonen_-_Tienraivaajia_Karjalassa.jpg "Enlarge")

_Pioneers in Karelia_ (1900) by [Pekka Halonen](/wiki/Pekka_Halonen "Pekka
Halonen")[40]

The [Finnish famine of 1866–1868](/wiki/Finnish_famine_of_1866%E2%80%931868
"Finnish famine of 1866–1868") killed 15% of the population, making it one of
the worst [famines](/wiki/Famine "Famine") in European history. The famine led
the Russian Empire to ease financial regulations, and investment rose in
following decades. Economic and political development was rapid.[41] The
[GDP](/wiki/Gross_domestic_product "Gross domestic product") per capita was
still half of that of the United States and a third of that of Britain.[41]

In 1906, [universal suffrage](/wiki/Universal_suffrage "Universal suffrage")
was adopted in the Grand Duchy of Finland. However, the relationship between
the Grand Duchy and the Russian Empire soured when the Russian government made
moves to restrict Finnish [autonomy](/wiki/Autonomous_area "Autonomous area").
For example, the universal suffrage was, in practice, virtually meaningless,
since the tsar did not have to approve any of the laws adopted by the Finnish
parliament. Desire for independence gained ground, first among radical
liberals[42] and socialists.

### Civil war and early
independence[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Finland&action=edit&section=8 "Edit
section: Civil war and early independence")]

Main articles: [Finnish Declaration of
Independence](/wiki/Finnish_Declaration_of_Independence "Finnish Declaration
of Independence") and [Finnish Civil War](/wiki/Finnish_Civil_War "Finnish
Civil War")

After the 1917 [February Revolution](/wiki/February_Revolution "February
Revolution"), the position of Finland as part of the Russian Empire was
questioned, mainly by [Social
Democrats](/wiki/Russian_Social_Democratic_Labour_Party "Russian Social
Democratic Labour Party"). Since the head of state was the [tsar](/wiki/Tsar
"Tsar") of Russia, it was not clear who the chief executive of Finland was
after the revolution. The Parliament, controlled by social democrats, passed
the so-called Power Act to give the highest authority to the Parliament. This
was rejected by the [Russian Provisional
Government](/wiki/Russian_Provisional_Government "Russian Provisional
Government") which decided to dissolve the Parliament.[43]

New elections were conducted, in which right-wing parties won a slim majority.
Some social democrats refused to accept the result and still claimed that the
dissolution of the parliament (and thus the ensuing elections) were
extralegal. The two nearly equally powerful political blocs, the right-wing
parties and the social democratic party, were highly antagonized.

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/f/fd/FiringsquadLankipohja.jpg/220px-
FiringsquadLankipohja.jpg)](/wiki/File:FiringsquadLankipohja.jpg)

[](/wiki/File:FiringsquadLankipohja.jpg "Enlarge")

White firing squad executing Red soldiers in Länkipohja,
[Längelmäki](/wiki/L%C3%A4ngelm%C3%A4ki "Längelmäki"), in 1918.

The [October Revolution](/wiki/October_Revolution "October Revolution") in
Russia changed the geopolitical situation anew. Suddenly, the right-wing
parties in Finland started to reconsider their decision to block the transfer
of highest executive power from the Russian government to Finland, as the
[Bolsheviks](/wiki/Bolsheviks "Bolsheviks") took power in Russia. Rather than
acknowledge the authority of the _Power Law_ of a few months earlier, the
right-wing government [declared
independence](/wiki/Finnish_Declaration_of_Independence "Finnish Declaration
of Independence") on 6 December 1917.

On 27 January 1918, the official opening shots of the war were fired in two
simultaneous events. The government started to disarm the Russian forces in
[Pohjanmaa](/wiki/Ostrobothnia_\(historical_province\) "Ostrobothnia
\(historical province\)"), and the [Social Democratic
Party](/wiki/Social_Democratic_Party_of_Finland "Social Democratic Party of
Finland") staged a coup.[_[not in citation
given](/wiki/Wikipedia:Verifiability "Wikipedia:Verifiability")_] The latter
succeeded in controlling southern Finland and Helsinki, but the white
government continued in exile from [Vaasa](/wiki/Vaasa "Vaasa"). This sparked
the brief but bitter [civil war](/wiki/Finnish_Civil_War "Finnish Civil War").
The [Whites](/wiki/White_Guard_\(Finland\) "White Guard \(Finland\)"), who
were supported by [Imperial Germany](/wiki/German_Empire "German Empire"),
prevailed over the [Reds](/wiki/Red_Guards_\(Finland\) "Red Guards
\(Finland\)").[44] After the war, tens of thousands of Reds and suspected
sympathizers were interned in camps, where thousands died by execution or from
malnutrition and disease. Deep social and political enmity was sown between
the Reds and Whites and would last until the [Winter War](/wiki/Winter_War
"Winter War") and beyond. The civil war and [activist
expeditions](/wiki/Heimosodat "Heimosodat") into Soviet Russia strained
Eastern relations.

After [a brief experimentation with
monarchy](/wiki/Kingdom_of_Finland_\(1918\) "Kingdom of Finland \(1918\)"),
Finland became a [presidential](/wiki/Presidential_system "Presidential
system") republic, with [Kaarlo Juho
Ståhlberg](/wiki/Kaarlo_Juho_St%C3%A5hlberg "Kaarlo Juho Ståhlberg") elected
as its first president in 1919. The Finnish–Russian border was determined by
the [Treaty of Tartu](/wiki/Treaty_of_Tartu_\(Russian%E2%80%93Finnish\)
"Treaty of Tartu \(Russian–Finnish\)") in 1920, largely following the historic
border but granting [Pechenga](/wiki/Pechengsky_District "Pechengsky
District") ([Finnish](/wiki/Finnish_language "Finnish language"): _Petsamo_)
and its [Barents Sea](/wiki/Barents_Sea "Barents Sea") harbour to Finland.
Finnish democracy did not see any Soviet coup attempts and survived the anti-
Communist [Lapua Movement](/wiki/Lapua_Movement "Lapua Movement"). The
relationship between Finland and the Soviet Union was tense. Germany's
relations with democratic Finland cooled also after the Nazis' rise to
power.[_[citation needed](/wiki/Wikipedia:Citation_needed "Wikipedia:Citation
needed")_] Army officers were trained in France, and relations to Western
Europe and Sweden were strengthened.

In 1917, the population was 3 million. Credit-based [land
reform](/wiki/Land_reform "Land reform") was enacted after the civil war,
increasing the proportion of capital-owning population.[41] About 70% of
workers were occupied in agriculture and 10% in industry.[45] The largest
export markets were the United Kingdom and Germany.

### World War II[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Finland&action=edit&section=9 "Edit
section: World War II")]

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/2/28/Finnish_areas_ceded_in_1944.png/220px-
Finnish_areas_ceded_in_1944.png)](/wiki/File:Finnish_areas_ceded_in_1944.png)

[](/wiki/File:Finnish_areas_ceded_in_1944.png "Enlarge")

Areas ceded by Finland to the [Soviet Union](/wiki/Soviet_Union "Soviet
Union") after the [Winter War](/wiki/Winter_War "Winter War") from 1939 to
1940 and the [Continuation War](/wiki/Continuation_War "Continuation War")
from 1941 to 1944. The [Porkkala](/wiki/Porkkala "Porkkala") land lease was
returned to Finland in 1956. Finland covered an area of approximately 385,000
km2 (149,000 sq mi) before the handover.

Main article: [Military history of Finland during World War
II](/wiki/Military_history_of_Finland_during_World_War_II "Military history of
Finland during World War II")

During [World War II](/wiki/World_War_II "World War II"), Finland fought the
[Soviet Union](/wiki/Soviet_Union "Soviet Union") twice: in the [Winter
War](/wiki/Winter_War "Winter War") of 1939–1940 after the Soviet Union had
attacked Finland; and in the [Continuation War](/wiki/Continuation_War
"Continuation War") of 1941–1944, following [Operation
Barbarossa](/wiki/Operation_Barbarossa "Operation Barbarossa"), during which
Finland aligned with Germany following Germany's invasion of the Soviet Union.
For 872 days, the German army, aided indirectly by Finnish forces, [besieged
Leningrad](/wiki/Siege_of_Leningrad "Siege of Leningrad"), the USSR's second
largest city.[46] After fighting a [major Soviet
offensive](/wiki/Vyborg%E2%80%93Petrozavodsk_Offensive "Vyborg–Petrozavodsk
Offensive") in June/July 1944 to a standstill, Finland reached an armistice
with the Soviet Union. This was followed by the [Lapland
War](/wiki/Lapland_War "Lapland War") of 1944–1945, when Finland fought
against the retreating German forces in northern Finland.

The treaties signed in 1947 and 1948 with the Soviet Union included Finnish
obligations, restraints, and reparations—as well as further Finnish
territorial concessions in addition to those in the [Moscow Peace
Treaty](/wiki/Moscow_Peace_Treaty "Moscow Peace Treaty") of 1940. As a result
of the two wars, Finland ceded most of [Finnish Karelia](/wiki/Finnish_Karelia
"Finnish Karelia"), [Salla](/wiki/Salla "Salla"), and
[Petsamo](/wiki/Pechengsky_District "Pechengsky District"), which amounted to
10% of its land area and 20% of its industrial capacity, including the ports
of [Vyborg](/wiki/Vyborg "Vyborg") (Viipuri) and the ice-free
[Liinakhamari](/wiki/Liinakhamari "Liinakhamari") (Liinahamari). [Almost the
whole population, some 400,000 people](/wiki/Evacuation_of_Finnish_Karelia
"Evacuation of Finnish Karelia"), fled these areas. Finland was never occupied
by Soviet forces and it retained its independence, but at the loss of about
93,000 soldiers.

Finland rejected [Marshall aid](/wiki/Marshall_aid "Marshall aid"), in
apparent [deference to Soviet desires](/wiki/Finlandization "Finlandization").
However, the United States provided secret development aid and helped the
(non-Communist) Social Democratic Party in hopes of preserving Finland's
independence.[47] Establishing trade with the Western powers, such as the
United Kingdom, and paying reparations to the Soviet Union produced a
transformation of Finland from a primarily [agrarian](/wiki/Agriculture
"Agriculture") economy to an industrialised one. For example, the
[Valmet](/wiki/Valmet "Valmet") corporation was founded to create materials
for war reparations, but, after the reparations had been paid off,
Finland—which was poor in certain resources necessary for an industrialized
nation (such as iron and oil)—continued to trade with the Soviet Union in the
framework of [bilateral trade](/wiki/Bilateral_trade "Bilateral trade").

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/f/f5/Urho_Kaleva_Kekkonen.jpg/170px-
Urho_Kaleva_Kekkonen.jpg)](/wiki/File:Urho_Kaleva_Kekkonen.jpg)

[](/wiki/File:Urho_Kaleva_Kekkonen.jpg "Enlarge")

[Urho Kekkonen](/wiki/Urho_Kekkonen "Urho Kekkonen"), the eighth president of
Finland (1956–1982)

In 1950, 46% of Finnish workers worked in agriculture and a third lived in
urban areas.[48] The new jobs in manufacturing, services, and trade quickly
attracted people to the towns. The average number of births per woman declined
from a [baby boom](/wiki/Baby_boom "Baby boom") peak of 3.5 in 1947 to 1.5 in
1973.[48] When baby-boomers entered the workforce, the economy did not
generate jobs fast enough, and hundreds of thousands emigrated to the more
industrialized Sweden, with emigration peaking in 1969 and 1970.[48] The [1952
Summer Olympics](/wiki/1952_Summer_Olympics "1952 Summer Olympics") brought
international visitors. Finland took part in trade liberalization in the
[World Bank](/wiki/World_Bank "World Bank"), the [International Monetary
Fund](/wiki/International_Monetary_Fund "International Monetary Fund") and the
[General Agreement on Tariffs and
Trade](/wiki/General_Agreement_on_Tariffs_and_Trade "General Agreement on
Tariffs and Trade").

Officially claiming to be [neutral](/wiki/Neutral_country "Neutral country"),
Finland lay in the grey zone between the [Western
countries](/wiki/Western_world "Western world") and the Soviet Union. The [YYA
Treaty](/wiki/Finno-Soviet_Treaty_of_1948 "Finno-Soviet Treaty of 1948")
(Finno-Soviet Pact of Friendship, Cooperation and Mutual Assistance) gave the
Soviet Union some leverage in Finnish domestic politics. This was extensively
exploited by president [Urho Kekkonen](/wiki/Urho_Kekkonen "Urho Kekkonen")
against his opponents. He maintained an effective monopoly on Soviet relations
from 1956 on, which was crucial for his continued popularity. In politics,
there was a tendency of avoiding any policies and statements that could be
interpreted as anti-Soviet. This phenomenon was given the name
"[Finlandization](/wiki/Finlandization "Finlandization")" by the West German
press.

Despite close relations with the Soviet Union, Finland maintained a market
economy. Various industries benefited from [trade
privileges](/wiki/Bilateral_trade "Bilateral trade") with the Soviets, which
explains the widespread support that pro-Soviet policies enjoyed among
business interests in Finland. Economic growth was rapid in the postwar era,
and by 1975 Finland's GDP per capita was the 15th highest in the world. In the
1970s and 80s, Finland built one of the most extensive [welfare
states](/wiki/Welfare_state "Welfare state") in the world. Finland negotiated
with the [EEC](/wiki/European_Economic_Community "European Economic
Community") (a predecessor of the European Union) a treaty that mostly
abolished customs duties towards the EEC starting from 1977, although Finland
did not fully join. In 1981, president [Urho Kekkonen](/wiki/Urho_Kekkonen
"Urho Kekkonen")'s failing health forced him to retire after holding office
for 25 years.

Finland reacted cautiously to the collapse of the Soviet Union, but swiftly
began increasing integration with the West. On 21 September 1990, Finland
unilaterally declared the [Paris Peace Treaty](/wiki/Paris_Peace_Treaty "Paris
Peace Treaty") obsolete, following the German reunification decision nine days
earlier.[49]

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/7/7c/Tratado_de_Lisboa_13_12_2007_%28081%29.jpg/220px-
Tratado_de_Lisboa_13_12_2007_%28081%29.jpg)](/wiki/File:Tratado_de_Lisboa_13_12_2007_\(081\).jpg)

[](/wiki/File:Tratado_de_Lisboa_13_12_2007_\(081\).jpg "Enlarge")

Finland joined the European Union in 1995 and signed the [Lisbon
Treaty](/wiki/Lisbon_Treaty "Lisbon Treaty") in 2007.

Miscalculated macroeconomic decisions, a [banking
crisis](/wiki/Finnish_banking_crisis_of_1990s "Finnish banking crisis of
1990s"), the collapse of its largest single trading partner (the Soviet
Union), and a global economic downturn caused a deep [early 1990s recession in
Finland](/wiki/Early_1990s_depression_in_Finland "Early 1990s depression in
Finland"). The depression bottomed out in 1993, and Finland saw steady
economic growth for more than ten years.[_[citation
needed](/wiki/Wikipedia:Citation_needed "Wikipedia:Citation needed")_] Like
other Nordic countries, Finland decentralised its economy since the late
1980s. Financial and product market regulation were loosened. Some state
enterprises have been privatized and there have been some modest tax
cuts.[_[citation needed](/wiki/Wikipedia:Citation_needed "Wikipedia:Citation
needed")_] Finland joined the [European Union](/wiki/European_Union "European
Union") in 1995, and the [Eurozone](/wiki/Eurozone "Eurozone") in 1999. Much
of the late 1990s economic growth was fueled by the phenomenal success of the
mobile phone manufacturer [Nokia](/wiki/Nokia "Nokia"), which held a unique
position of representing 80% of the market capitalization of the [Helsinki
Stock Exchange](/wiki/Helsinki_Stock_Exchange "Helsinki Stock Exchange").

## Language[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Finland&action=edit&section=10 "Edit
section: Language")]

Main articles: [Finnish language](/wiki/Finnish_language "Finnish language"),
[Finland Swedish](/wiki/Finland_Swedish "Finland Swedish"), and [Languages of
Finland](/wiki/Languages_of_Finland "Languages of Finland")

Finnish and [Swedish](/wiki/Swedish_language "Swedish language") are the
official languages of Finland. Finnish predominates nationwide while Swedish
is spoken in some coastal areas in the west and south and in the autonomous
region of [Åland](/wiki/%C3%85land "Åland"). The [native
language](/wiki/Native_language "Native language") of 89% of the population is
Finnish,[50] which is part of the Finnic subgroup of the Uralic languages. The
language is one of only four official [EU
languages](/wiki/Languages_of_the_European_Union "Languages of the European
Union") not of [Indo-European](/wiki/Indo-European_languages "Indo-European
languages") origin. Finnish is closely related to
[Karelian](/wiki/Karelian_language "Karelian language") and
[Estonian](/wiki/Estonian_language "Estonian language") and more remotely to
the Sami languages and [Hungarian](/wiki/Hungarian_language "Hungarian
language"). Swedish is the native language of 5.3% of the population
([Swedish-speaking Finns](/wiki/Swedish-speaking_Finns "Swedish-speaking
Finns")).[51]

The [Nordic](/wiki/Nordic_countries "Nordic countries") languages and
[Karelian](/wiki/Karelian_language "Karelian language") are also specially
treated in some contexts.

[Finnish Romani](/wiki/Finnish_Kalo_language "Finnish Kalo language") is
spoken by some 5,000–6,000 people, [Finnish
Romani](/wiki/Kalo_Finnish_Romani_language "Kalo Finnish Romani language") and
[Finnish Sign Language](/wiki/Finnish_Sign_Language "Finnish Sign Language")
are also recognized in the constitution. There are two sign languages:
[Finnish Sign Language](/wiki/Finnish_Sign_Language "Finnish Sign Language"),
spoken natively by 4,000–5,000 people,[52] and [Finland-Swedish Sign
Language](/wiki/Finland-Swedish_Sign_Language "Finland-Swedish Sign
Language"), spoken natively by about 150 people. Tatar language is spoken by a
[Finnish Tatar](/wiki/Finnish_Tatars "Finnish Tatars") minority of about 800
people who moved to Finland mainly during the Russian rule from the 1870s
until the 1920s.[53]

The [Sami language](/wiki/Sami_languages "Sami languages") is an official
language to the north, in Lapland or in northern Lapland, where are the Sami
people, numbering around 7,000[54] and recognized as an [indigenous
people](/wiki/Indigenous_peoples "Indigenous peoples"). About a quarter of
them speak a [Sami language](/wiki/Sami_languages "Sami languages") as their
mother tongue.[55] The Sami languages that are spoken in Finland are [Northern
Sami](/wiki/Northern_Sami "Northern Sami"), [Inari
Sami](/wiki/Inari_Sami_language "Inari Sami language"), and [Skolt
Sami](/wiki/Skolt_Sami_language "Skolt Sami language").[note 1]

The rights of minority groups (in particular [Sami](/wiki/Sami_people#Finland
"Sami people"), [Swedish speakers](/wiki/Swedish-
speaking_population_of_Finland "Swedish-speaking population of Finland"), and
[Romani people](/wiki/Finnish_Kale "Finnish Kale")) are protected by the
constitution.[56]

The largest immigrant languages are Russian (1.4%), Estonian (0.9%), Arabic
(0.4%), Somali (0.3%) and English (0.3%).[51] English is studied by most
pupils as a compulsory subject from the third or fifth grade (at 9 or 11 years
of age respectively) in the comprehensive school (in some schools other
languages can be chosen instead). German, French, and Russian can be studied
as second foreign languages from the eighth grade (at 14 years of age; some
schools may offer other options).[_[citation
needed](/wiki/Wikipedia:Citation_needed "Wikipedia:Citation needed")_]

## Geography[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Finland&action=edit&section=11 "Edit
section: Geography")]

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/1/1f/Map_of_Finland-
en.svg/170px-Map_of_Finland-en.svg.png)](/wiki/File:Map_of_Finland-en.svg)

[](/wiki/File:Map_of_Finland-en.svg "Enlarge")

Detailed map of Finland. (See also [Atlas of
Finland](https://commons.wikimedia.org/wiki/Atlas_of_Finland "commons:Atlas of
Finland").)

Main article: [Geography of Finland](/wiki/Geography_of_Finland "Geography of
Finland")

See also: [List of cities and towns in
Finland](/wiki/List_of_cities_and_towns_in_Finland "List of cities and towns
in Finland"), [List of lakes in Finland](/wiki/List_of_lakes_in_Finland "List
of lakes in Finland"), [List of national parks of
Finland](/wiki/List_of_national_parks_of_Finland "List of national parks of
Finland"), and [Environmental issues in
Finland](/wiki/Environmental_issues_in_Finland "Environmental issues in
Finland")

Lying approximately between latitudes [60°](/wiki/60th_parallel_north "60th
parallel north") and [70° N](/wiki/70th_parallel_north "70th parallel north"),
and longitudes [20°](/wiki/20th_meridian_east "20th meridian east") and [32°
E](/wiki/32nd_meridian_east "32nd meridian east"), Finland is one of the
world's northernmost countries. Of world capitals, only
[Reykjavík](/wiki/Reykjav%C3%ADk "Reykjavík") lies more to the north than
[Helsinki](/wiki/Helsinki "Helsinki"). The distance from the southernmost
point – [Hanko](/wiki/Hanko "Hanko") in Uusimaa – to the northernmost –
[Nuorgam](/wiki/Nuorgam "Nuorgam") in Lapland – is 1,160 kilometres (720 mi).

Finland has about 168,000 lakes (of area larger than 500 m2 or 0.12 acres) and
179,000 islands.[57] Its largest lake, [Saimaa](/wiki/Saimaa "Saimaa"), is the
fourth largest in Europe. The [Finnish Lakeland](/wiki/Finnish_Lakeland
"Finnish Lakeland") is the area with the most lakes in the country. The
greatest concentration of islands is found in the southwest, in the
[Archipelago Sea](/wiki/Archipelago_Sea "Archipelago Sea") between continental
Finland and the main island of Åland.

Much of the geography of Finland is a result of the Ice Age. The glaciers were
thicker and lasted longer in [Fennoscandia](/wiki/Fennoscandia "Fennoscandia")
compared with the rest of Europe. Their eroding effects have left the Finnish
landscape mostly flat with few hills and fewer mountains. Its highest point,
the [Halti](/wiki/Halti "Halti") at 1,324 metres (4,344 ft), is found in the
extreme north of Lapland at the border between Finland and
[Norway](/wiki/Norway "Norway"). The highest mountain whose peak is entirely
in Finland is [Ridnitšohkka](/wiki/Ridnit%C5%A1ohkka "Ridnitšohkka") at 1,316
m (4,318 ft), directly adjacent to Halti.

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/f/fe/Cygnus_cygnus_from_zh.JPG/220px-
Cygnus_cygnus_from_zh.JPG)](/wiki/File:Cygnus_cygnus_from_zh.JPG)

[](/wiki/File:Cygnus_cygnus_from_zh.JPG "Enlarge")

The [whooper swan](/wiki/Whooper_swan "Whooper swan"), Finland's [national
bird](/wiki/List_of_national_birds "List of national birds")

The retreating glaciers have left the land with [morainic](/wiki/Moraine
"Moraine") deposits in formations of [eskers](/wiki/Esker "Esker"). These are
ridges of stratified gravel and sand, running northwest to southeast, where
the ancient edge of the glacier once lay. Among the biggest of these are the
three [Salpausselkä](/wiki/Salpausselk%C3%A4 "Salpausselkä") ridges that run
across southern Finland.

Having been compressed under the enormous weight of the glaciers, terrain in
Finland is rising due to the [post-glacial rebound](/wiki/Post-glacial_rebound
"Post-glacial rebound"). The effect is strongest around the [Gulf of
Bothnia](/wiki/Gulf_of_Bothnia "Gulf of Bothnia"), where land steadily rises
about 1 cm (0.4 in) a year. As a result, the old sea bottom turns little by
little into dry land: the surface area of the country is expanding by about 7
square kilometres (2.7 sq mi) annually.[58] Relatively speaking, Finland is
rising from the sea.[59]

The landscape is covered mostly by coniferous [taiga](/wiki/Taiga "Taiga")
forests and [fens](/wiki/Fen "Fen"), with little cultivated land. Of the total
area 10% is lakes, rivers and ponds, and 78% forest. The forest consists of
[pine](/wiki/Pine "Pine"), [spruce](/wiki/Spruce "Spruce"),
[birch](/wiki/Birch "Birch"), and other species.[60] Finland is the largest
producer of wood in Europe and among the largest in the world. The most common
type of rock is [granite](/wiki/Granite "Granite"). It is a ubiquitous part of
the scenery, visible wherever there is no soil cover. Moraine or
[till](/wiki/Till "Till") is the most common type of soil, covered by a thin
layer of [humus](/wiki/Humus "Humus") of biological origin.
[Podzol](/wiki/Podzol "Podzol") profile development is seen in most forest
soils except where drainage is poor. [Gleysols](/wiki/Gleysol "Gleysol") and
peat [bogs](/wiki/Bog "Bog") occupy poorly drained areas.

### Biodiversity[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Finland&action=edit&section=12
"Edit section: Biodiversity")]

Main articles: [Fauna of Finland](/wiki/Fauna_of_Finland "Fauna of Finland")
and [Wildlife of Finland](/wiki/Wildlife_of_Finland "Wildlife of Finland")

[Phytogeographically](/wiki/Phytogeography "Phytogeography"), Finland is
shared between the Arctic, central European, and northern European provinces
of the [Circumboreal Region](/wiki/Circumboreal_Region "Circumboreal Region")
within the [Boreal Kingdom](/wiki/Boreal_Kingdom "Boreal Kingdom"). According
to the [WWF](/wiki/World_Wide_Fund_for_Nature "World Wide Fund for Nature"),
the territory of Finland can be subdivided into three
[ecoregions](/wiki/Ecoregion "Ecoregion"): the [Scandinavian and Russian
taiga](/wiki/Scandinavian_and_Russian_taiga "Scandinavian and Russian taiga"),
[Sarmatic mixed forests](/wiki/Sarmatic_mixed_forests "Sarmatic mixed
forests"), and [Scandinavian Montane Birch forest and
grasslands](/wiki/Scandinavian_Montane_Birch_forest_and_grasslands
"Scandinavian Montane Birch forest and grasslands"). Taiga covers most of
Finland from northern regions of southern provinces to the north of Lapland.
On the southwestern coast, south of the Helsinki-[Rauma](/wiki/Rauma,_Finland
"Rauma, Finland") line, forests are characterized by mixed forests, that are
more typical in the Baltic region. In the extreme north of Finland, near the
[tree line](/wiki/Tree_line "Tree line") and Arctic Ocean, Montane Birch
forests are common.

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/2/27/Bear_Finland.png/220px-
Bear_Finland.png)](/wiki/File:Bear_Finland.png)

[](/wiki/File:Bear_Finland.png "Enlarge")

The [brown bear](/wiki/Brown_bear "Brown bear") (_Ursus arctos_) is Finland's
national animal.

Similarly, Finland has a diverse and extensive range of fauna. There are at
least sixty native [mammalian](/wiki/Mammal "Mammal") species, 248 breeding
bird species, over 70 fish species, and 11 reptile and frog species present
today, many migrating from neighboring countries thousands of years ago. Large
and widely recognized wildlife mammals found in Finland are the [brown
bear](/wiki/Brown_bear "Brown bear") (the national animal), [gray
wolf](/wiki/Gray_wolf "Gray wolf"), [wolverine](/wiki/Wolverine "Wolverine"),
and [elk](/wiki/Moose "Moose"). Three of the more striking birds are the
[whooper swan](/wiki/Whooper_swan "Whooper swan"), a large European swan and
the national bird of Finland; the [Western
capercaillie](/wiki/Western_capercaillie "Western capercaillie"), a large,
black-plumaged member of the [grouse](/wiki/Grouse "Grouse") family; and the
[Eurasian eagle-owl](/wiki/Eurasian_eagle-owl "Eurasian eagle-owl"). The
latter is considered an indicator of [old-growth forest](/wiki/Old-
growth_forest "Old-growth forest") connectivity, and has been declining
because of landscape fragmentation.[61] The most common breeding birds are the
[willow warbler](/wiki/Willow_warbler "Willow warbler"), [common
chaffinch](/wiki/Common_chaffinch "Common chaffinch"), and
[redwing](/wiki/Redwing "Redwing").[62] Of some seventy species of freshwater
fish, the [northern pike](/wiki/Northern_pike "Northern pike"),
[perch](/wiki/Perch "Perch"), and others are plentiful. [Atlantic
salmon](/wiki/Atlantic_salmon "Atlantic salmon") remains the favourite of [fly
rod](/wiki/Fly_fishing "Fly fishing") enthusiasts.

The endangered [Saimaa ringed seal](/wiki/Saimaa_ringed_seal "Saimaa ringed
seal"), one of only three lake seal species in the world, exists only in the
[Saimaa](/wiki/Saimaa "Saimaa") lake system of southeastern Finland, down to
only 300 seals today. It has become the emblem of the Finnish Association for
Nature Conservation.[63]

### Climate[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Finland&action=edit&section=13 "Edit
section: Climate")]

Main article: [Climate of Finland](/wiki/Climate_of_Finland "Climate of
Finland")

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/6/6f/Finland_koppen.svg/220px-
Finland_koppen.svg.png)](/wiki/File:Finland_koppen.svg)

[](/wiki/File:Finland_koppen.svg "Enlarge")

[Köppen climate classification](/wiki/K%C3%B6ppen_climate_classification
"Köppen climate classification") types of Finland

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/d/d1/Koli_National_Park_in_Northern_Karelia.jpg/220px-
Koli_National_Park_in_Northern_Karelia.jpg)](/wiki/File:Koli_National_Park_in_Northern_Karelia.jpg)

[](/wiki/File:Koli_National_Park_in_Northern_Karelia.jpg "Enlarge")

[Koli National Park](/wiki/Koli_National_Park "Koli National Park") in North
Karelia

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/8/8b/Repoveden_Kansallispuisto_Kesayonauringossa.jpg/220px-
Repoveden_Kansallispuisto_Kesayonauringossa.jpg)](/wiki/File:Repoveden_Kansallispuisto_Kesayonauringossa.jpg)

[](/wiki/File:Repoveden_Kansallispuisto_Kesayonauringossa.jpg "Enlarge")

[Repovesi National Park](/wiki/Repovesi_National_Park "Repovesi National
Park") in southeastern Finland

The main factor influencing Finland's climate is the country's geographical
position between the 60th and 70th northern parallels in the
[Eurasian](/wiki/Eurasia "Eurasia") continent's coastal zone. In the [Köppen
climate classification](/wiki/K%C3%B6ppen_climate_classification "Köppen
climate classification"), the whole of Finland lies in the [boreal
zone](/wiki/Subarctic_climate "Subarctic climate"), characterized by warm
summers and freezing winters. Within the country, the
[temperateness](/wiki/Temperateness "Temperateness") varies considerably
between the southern coastal regions and the extreme north, showing
characteristics of both a [maritime](/wiki/Oceanic_climate "Oceanic climate")
and a [continental climate](/wiki/Continental_climate "Continental climate").
Finland is near enough to the Atlantic Ocean to be continuously warmed by the
[Gulf Stream](/wiki/Gulf_Stream "Gulf Stream"). The Gulf Stream combines with
the moderating effects of the [Baltic Sea](/wiki/Baltic_Sea "Baltic Sea") and
numerous inland lakes to explain the unusually warm climate compared with
other regions that share the same [latitude](/wiki/Latitude "Latitude"), such
as [Alaska](/wiki/Alaska "Alaska"), [Siberia](/wiki/Siberia "Siberia"), and
southern [Greenland](/wiki/Greenland "Greenland").[64]

Winters in southern Finland (when mean daily temperature remains below 0 °C or
32 °F) are usually about 100 days long, and in the inland the snow typically
covers the land from about late November to April, and on the coastal areas
such as [Helsinki](/wiki/Helsinki "Helsinki"), snow often covers the land from
late December to late March.[65] Even in the south, the harshest winter nights
can see the temperatures fall to −30 °C (−22 °F) although on coastal areas
like Helsinki, temperatures below −30 °C (−22 °F) are very rare. Climatic
summers (when mean daily temperature remains above 10 °C or 50 °F) in southern
Finland last from about late May to mid-September, and in the inland, the
warmest days of July can reach over 35 °C (95 °F).[64] Although most of
Finland lies on the [taiga](/wiki/Taiga "Taiga") belt, the southernmost
coastal regions are sometimes classified as [hemiboreal](/wiki/Hemiboreal
"Hemiboreal").[66]

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/4/49/Isokuru.JPG/220px-
Isokuru.JPG)](/wiki/File:Isokuru.JPG)

[](/wiki/File:Isokuru.JPG "Enlarge")

[Pyhä-Luosto National Park](/wiki/Pyh%C3%A4-Luosto_National_Park "Pyhä-Luosto
National Park"), [Lapland](/wiki/Lapland_\(Finland\) "Lapland \(Finland\)")

In northern Finland, particularly in Lapland, the winters are long and cold,
while the summers are relatively warm but short. The most severe winter days
in Lapland can see the temperature fall down to −45 °C (−49 °F). The winter of
the north lasts for about 200 days with permanent snow cover from about mid-
October to early May. Summers in the north are quite short, only two to three
months, but can still see maximum daily temperatures above 25 °C (77 °F)
during heat waves.[64] No part of Finland has [Arctic
tundra](/wiki/Arctic_tundra "Arctic tundra"), but [Alpine
tundra](/wiki/Alpine_tundra "Alpine tundra") can be found at the
[fells](/wiki/Fell "Fell") Lapland.[66]

The Finnish climate is suitable for cereal farming only in the southernmost
regions, while the northern regions are suitable for [animal
husbandry](/wiki/Animal_husbandry "Animal husbandry").[67]

A quarter of Finland's territory lies within the [Arctic
Circle](/wiki/Arctic_Circle "Arctic Circle") and the [midnight
sun](/wiki/Midnight_sun "Midnight sun") can be experienced for more days the
farther north one travels. At Finland's northernmost point, the sun does not
set for 73 consecutive days during summer, and does not rise at all for 51
days during winter.[64]

### Regions[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Finland&action=edit&section=14 "Edit
section: Regions")]

Main article: [Regions of Finland](/wiki/Regions_of_Finland "Regions of
Finland")

Finland consists of 19 [regions](/wiki/Regions_of_Finland "Regions of
Finland") called **maakunta** in Finnish and **landskap** in Swedish. The
regions are governed by regional councils which serve as forums of cooperation
for the [municipalities](/wiki/Municipalities_of_Finland "Municipalities of
Finland") of a region. The main tasks of the regions are regional planning and
development of enterprise and education. In addition, the public health
services are usually organized on the basis of regions. Currently, the only
region where a popular election is held for the council is Kainuu. Other
regional councils are elected by municipal councils, each municipality sending
representatives in proportion to its population.

In addition to inter-municipal cooperation, which is the responsibility of
regional councils, each region has a state Employment and Economic Development
Centre which is responsible for the local administration of labour,
agriculture, fisheries, forestry, and entrepreneurial affairs. The [Finnish
Defence Forces](/wiki/Finnish_Defence_Forces "Finnish Defence Forces")
regional offices are responsible for the regional defence preparations and for
the administration of conscription within the region.

Regions represent dialectal, cultural, and economic variations better than the
former [provinces](/wiki/Provinces_of_Finland "Provinces of Finland"), which
were purely administrative divisions of the central government. Historically,
regions are divisions of [historical provinces of
Finland](/wiki/Historical_provinces_of_Finland "Historical provinces of
Finland"), areas which represent dialects and culture more accurately.

Six [Regional State Administrative
Agencies](/wiki/Regional_State_Administrative_Agencies_of_Finland "Regional
State Administrative Agencies of Finland") were created by the state of
Finland in 2010, each of them responsible for one of the regions called _alue_
in Finnish and _region_ in Swedish; in addition, Åland was designated a
seventh region. These take over some of the tasks of the earlier [Provinces of
Finland](/wiki/Provinces_of_Finland "Provinces of Finland") (the _lääni_ s),
which were abolished.[68]

### Administrative
divisions[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Finland&action=edit&section=15 "Edit
section: Administrative divisions")]

Main articles: [Administrative divisions of
Finland](/wiki/Administrative_divisions_of_Finland "Administrative divisions
of Finland"), [Regions of Finland](/wiki/Regions_of_Finland "Regions of
Finland"), [Sub-regions of Finland](/wiki/Sub-regions_of_Finland "Sub-regions
of Finland"), [Municipalities of Finland](/wiki/Municipalities_of_Finland
"Municipalities of Finland"), and [Historical provinces of
Finland](/wiki/Historical_provinces_of_Finland "Historical provinces of
Finland")

Further information: [List of Finnish
municipalities](/wiki/List_of_Finnish_municipalities "List of Finnish
municipalities"), [List of Finnish municipalities by
population](/wiki/List_of_Finnish_municipalities_by_population "List of
Finnish municipalities by population"), [List of Finnish municipalities by
area](/wiki/List_of_Finnish_municipalities_by_area "List of Finnish
municipalities by area"), and [Former municipalities of
Finland](/wiki/Former_municipalities_of_Finland "Former municipalities of
Finland")

The fundamental administrative divisions of the country are the
[municipalities](/wiki/Municipalities_of_Finland "Municipalities of Finland"),
which may also call themselves towns or cities. They account for half of
public spending. Spending is financed by municipal income tax, state
subsidies, and other revenue. As of
2017[[update]](//en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=Finland&action=edit),
there are 311 municipalities,[9] and most have fewer than 6,000 residents.

In addition to municipalities, two intermediate levels are defined.
Municipalities co-operate in seventy [sub-regions](/wiki/Sub-
regions_of_Finland "Sub-regions of Finland") and nineteen
[regions](/wiki/Regions_of_Finland "Regions of Finland"). These are governed
by the member municipalities and have only limited powers. The autonomous
province of Åland has a permanent democratically elected regional council. In
the [Kainuu](/wiki/Kainuu "Kainuu") region, there is a pilot project underway
with regional elections. Sami people have a semi-autonomous [Sami native
region](/wiki/Sami_native_region_\(Finland\) "Sami native region \(Finland\)")
in Lapland for issues on language and culture.

In the following chart, the number of inhabitants includes those living in the
entire municipality (_kunta/kommun_), not just in the built-up area. The land
area is given in km², and the density in inhabitants per km² (land area). The
figures are as of 31 August 2017. The [capital region](/wiki/Capital_region
"Capital region") – comprising [Helsinki](/wiki/Helsinki "Helsinki"),
[Vantaa](/wiki/Vantaa "Vantaa"), [Espoo](/wiki/Espoo "Espoo") and
[Kauniainen](/wiki/Kauniainen "Kauniainen") – forms a continuous
[conurbation](/wiki/Conurbation "Conurbation") of over 1.1 million people.
However, common administration is limited to voluntary cooperation of all
municipalities, e.g. in [Helsinki Metropolitan Area
Council](/wiki/Helsinki_Metropolitan_Area_Council "Helsinki Metropolitan Area
Council").

## Politics[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Finland&action=edit&section=16 "Edit
section: Politics")]

Main article: [Politics of Finland](/wiki/Politics_of_Finland "Politics of
Finland")

See also: [List of political parties in
Finland](/wiki/List_of_political_parties_in_Finland "List of political parties
in Finland") and [Human rights in Finland](/wiki/Human_rights_in_Finland
"Human rights in Finland")

### Constitution[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Finland&action=edit&section=17
"Edit section: Constitution")]

The [Constitution of Finland](/wiki/Constitution_of_Finland "Constitution of
Finland") defines the political system; Finland is a [parliamentary
republic](/wiki/Parliamentary_republic "Parliamentary republic") within the
framework of a [representative democracy](/wiki/Representative_democracy
"Representative democracy"). The [Prime
Minister](/wiki/Prime_Minister_of_Finland "Prime Minister of Finland") is the
country's most powerful person. The current version of the constitution was
enacted on 1 March 2000, and was amended on 1 March 2012. Citizens can run and
vote in parliamentary, municipal, presidential and [European Union
elections](/wiki/Elections_in_the_European_Union "Elections in the European
Union").

### President[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Finland&action=edit&section=18 "Edit
section: President")]

Main article: [President of Finland](/wiki/President_of_Finland "President of
Finland")

The [head of state](/wiki/Head_of_state "Head of state") of Finland is
[President of the Republic of Finland](/wiki/President_of_Finland "President
of Finland") (in Finnish: _Suomen tasavallan presidentti_ ; in Swedish:
_Republiken Finlands president_). Finland has had for most of its independence
a [semi-presidential system](/wiki/Semi-presidential_system "Semi-presidential
system"), but in the last few decades the powers of the President have been
diminished. In constitution amendments, which came into effect in 1991 or 1992
and also with a new drafted constitution of 2000, amended in 2012, the
President's position has become primarily a ceremonial office. However, the
President still leads the nation's foreign politics together with the Council
of State and is the chief-in-command of the Defence Forces.[1] The position
still does entail some powers, including responsibility for [foreign
policy](/wiki/Foreign_relations_of_Finland "Foreign relations of Finland")
(excluding affairs related to the [European Union](/wiki/European_Union
"European Union")) in cooperation with the [cabinet](/wiki/Finnish_Government
"Finnish Government"), being [the head of the armed forces](/wiki/Commander-
in-Chief "Commander-in-Chief"), some decree powers, and some appointive
powers. Direct, one- or two-stage elections are used to elect the president
for a term of six years and for a maximum of two consecutive terms. The
current president is [Sauli Niinistö](/wiki/Sauli_Niinist%C3%B6 "Sauli
Niinistö"); he took office on 1 March 2012. Former presidents were [K. J.
Ståhlberg](/wiki/Kaarlo_Juho_St%C3%A5hlberg "Kaarlo Juho Ståhlberg")
(1919–1925), [L. K. Relander](/wiki/Lauri_Kristian_Relander "Lauri Kristian
Relander") (1925–1931), [P. E. Svinhufvud](/wiki/Pehr_Evind_Svinhufvud "Pehr
Evind Svinhufvud") (1931–1937), [Kyösti Kallio](/wiki/Ky%C3%B6sti_Kallio
"Kyösti Kallio") (1937–1940), [Risto Ryti](/wiki/Risto_Ryti "Risto Ryti")
(1940–1944), [C. G. E. Mannerheim](/wiki/Carl_Gustaf_Emil_Mannerheim "Carl
Gustaf Emil Mannerheim") (1944–1946), [J. K.
Paasikivi](/wiki/Juho_Kusti_Paasikivi "Juho Kusti Paasikivi") (1946–1956),
[Urho Kekkonen](/wiki/Urho_Kekkonen "Urho Kekkonen") (1956–1982), [Mauno
Koivisto](/wiki/Mauno_Koivisto "Mauno Koivisto") (1982–1994), [Martti
Ahtisaari](/wiki/Martti_Ahtisaari "Martti Ahtisaari") (1994–2000), and [Tarja
Halonen](/wiki/Tarja_Halonen "Tarja Halonen") (2000–2012).

The current president was elected from the ranks of the [National Coalition
Party](/wiki/National_Coalition_Party "National Coalition Party") for the
first time since 1946. The presidency between 1946 and the present was instead
held by a member of the [Social Democratic
Party](/wiki/Social_Democratic_Party_of_Finland "Social Democratic Party of
Finland") or the [Centre Party](/wiki/Centre_Party_\(Finland\) "Centre Party
\(Finland\)").

### Parliament[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Finland&action=edit&section=19 "Edit
section: Parliament")]

Main article: [Parliament of Finland](/wiki/Parliament_of_Finland "Parliament
of Finland")

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/d/dd/Eduskuntatalo_Helsinki.jpg/220px-
Eduskuntatalo_Helsinki.jpg)](/wiki/File:Eduskuntatalo_Helsinki.jpg)

[](/wiki/File:Eduskuntatalo_Helsinki.jpg "Enlarge")

The [Parliament of Finland](/wiki/Parliament_of_Finland "Parliament of
Finland")'s main building.

The 200-member [unicameral](/wiki/Unicameralism "Unicameralism") [Parliament
of Finland](/wiki/Parliament_of_Finland "Parliament of Finland")
([Finnish](/wiki/Finnish_language "Finnish language"): _Eduskunta_ ,
[Swedish](/wiki/Swedish_language "Swedish language"): _Riksdag_) exercises
supreme legislative authority in the country. It may alter the constitution
and ordinary laws, dismiss the cabinet, and override presidential vetoes. Its
acts are not subject to judicial review; the constitutionality of new laws is
assessed by the parliament's [constitutional law
committee](/wiki/Parliament_of_Finland#Committees "Parliament of Finland").
The parliament is elected for a term of four years using the proportional
[D'Hondt method](/wiki/D%27Hondt_method "D'Hondt method") within a number of
multi-seat constituencies through open list multi-member districts. Various
parliament committees listen to experts and prepare legislation. The [speaker
of the parliament](/wiki/Speaker_of_the_Parliament_of_Finland "Speaker of the
Parliament of Finland") is [Maria Lohela](/wiki/Maria_Lohela "Maria Lohela")
([sin.](/wiki/Blue_Reform "Blue Reform")).[73]

Since [universal suffrage](/wiki/Universal_suffrage "Universal suffrage") was
introduced in 1906, the parliament has been dominated by the [Centre
Party](/wiki/Centre_Party_\(Finland\) "Centre Party \(Finland\)") (former
Agrarian Union), the [National Coalition Party](/wiki/National_Coalition_Party
"National Coalition Party"), and the [Social
Democrats](/wiki/Social_Democratic_Party_of_Finland "Social Democratic Party
of Finland"). These parties have enjoyed approximately equal support, and
their combined vote has totalled about 65–80% of all votes. Their lowest
common total of MPs, 121, was reached in the 2011 elections. For a few decades
after 1944, the [Communists](/wiki/Communist_Party_of_Finland "Communist Party
of Finland") were a strong fourth party. Due to the electoral system of
proportional representation, and the relative reluctance of voters to switch
their support between parties, the relative strengths of the parties have
commonly varied only slightly from one election to another. However, there
have been some long-term trends, such as the rise and fall of the Communists
during the Cold War; the steady decline into insignificance of the
[Liberals](/wiki/Liberals_\(Finland\) "Liberals \(Finland\)") and its
predecessors from 1906 to 1980; and the rise of the [Green
League](/wiki/Green_League "Green League") since 1983. In the 2011 elections,
the [Finns Party](/wiki/True_Finns "True Finns") achieved exceptional success,
increasing its representation from 5 to 39 seats, surpassing the Centre
Party.[74]

The autonomous province of Åland, which forms a [federacy](/wiki/Federacy
"Federacy") with Finland, elects one member to the parliament, who
traditionally joins the [parliamentary group](/wiki/Parliamentary_group
"Parliamentary group") of the [Swedish People's Party of
Finland](/wiki/Swedish_People%27s_Party_of_Finland "Swedish People's Party of
Finland"). (The province also holds elections for its own permanent [regional
council](/wiki/Parliament_of_%C3%85land "Parliament of Åland"), and in the
[2011 elections](/wiki/%C3%85land_legislative_election,_2011 "Åland
legislative election, 2011"), [Åland Centre](/wiki/%C3%85land_Centre "Åland
Centre") was the largest party.)

The Parliament can be dissolved by a recommendation of the Prime Minister,
endorsed by the President. This procedure has never been used, although the
parliament was dissolved eight times under the pre-2000 constitution, when
this action was the sole prerogative of the president.
