### Cabinet[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Finland&action=edit&section=20 "Edit
section: Cabinet")]

After parliamentary elections, the parties negotiate among themselves on
forming a new cabinet (the [Finnish Government](/wiki/Finnish_Government
"Finnish Government")), which then has to be approved by a simple majority
vote in the parliament. The cabinet can be dismissed by a parliamentary vote
of no confidence, although this rarely happens (the last time in 1957), as the
parties represented in the cabinet usually make up a majority in the
parliament.[76]

The cabinet exercises most executive powers, and originates most of the bills
that the parliament then debates and votes on. It is headed by the [Prime
Minister of Finland](/wiki/Prime_Minister_of_Finland "Prime Minister of
Finland"), and consists of him or her, of other ministers, and of the
[Chancellor of Justice](/wiki/Chancellor_of_Justice#Finland "Chancellor of
Justice"). The current prime minister is [Juha Sipilä](/wiki/Juha_Sipil%C3%A4
"Juha Sipilä") (Centre Party). Each minister heads his or her ministry, or, in
some cases, has responsibility for a subset of a ministry's policy. After the
prime minister, the most powerful minister is the [minister of
finance](/wiki/Minister_of_Finance_\(Finland\) "Minister of Finance
\(Finland\)"). The incumbent Minister of Finance is [Petteri
Orpo](/wiki/Petteri_Orpo "Petteri Orpo").

As no one party ever dominates the parliament, Finnish cabinets are multi-
party coalitions. As a rule, the post of prime minister goes to the leader of
the biggest party and that of the minister of finance to the leader of the
second biggest.

### Law[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Finland&action=edit&section=21 "Edit
section: Law")]

Main articles: [Law of Finland](/wiki/Law_of_Finland "Law of Finland") and
[Judicial system of Finland](/wiki/Judicial_system_of_Finland "Judicial system
of Finland")

The judicial system of Finland is a [civil
law](/wiki/Civil_law_\(legal_system\) "Civil law \(legal system\)") system
divided between [courts](/wiki/Court "Court") with regular civil and criminal
jurisdiction and [administrative courts](/wiki/Administrative_court
"Administrative court") with jurisdiction over litigation between individuals
and the public administration. Finnish law is codified and based on [Swedish
law](/wiki/Judiciary_of_Sweden "Judiciary of Sweden") and in a wider sense,
civil law or [Roman law](/wiki/Roman_law "Roman law"). The court system for
civil and criminal jurisdiction consists of local courts (_käräjäoikeus_ ,
_tingsrätt_), regional appellate courts (_hovioikeus_ , _hovrätt_), and the
[Supreme Court](/wiki/Judicial_system_of_Finland#Supreme_Court "Judicial
system of Finland") (_korkein oikeus_ , _högsta domstolen_). The
administrative branch of justice consists of administrative courts (_hallinto-
oikeus_ , _förvaltningsdomstol_) and the [Supreme Administrative
Court](/wiki/Judicial_system_of_Finland#Supreme_Administrative_Court "Judicial
system of Finland") (_korkein hallinto-oikeus_ , _högsta
förvaltningsdomstolen_). In addition to the regular courts, there are a few
special courts in certain branches of administration. There is also a [High
Court of
Impeachment](/wiki/Judicial_system_of_Finland#High_Court_of_Impeachment
"Judicial system of Finland") for criminal charges against certain high-
ranking officeholders.

Around 92% of residents have confidence in Finland's security
institutions.[77] The overall [crime rate of Finland](/wiki/Crime_in_Finland
"Crime in Finland") is not high in the EU context. Some crime types are above
average, notably the highest [homicide](/wiki/Homicide "Homicide") rate in
Western Europe.[78] A [day fine](/wiki/Day_fine "Day fine") system is in
effect and also applied to offenses such as [speeding](/wiki/Speeding
"Speeding").

Finland has successfully fought against government corruption, which was more
common in the 1970s and 80s.[79][_[verification
needed](/wiki/Wikipedia:Verifiability "Wikipedia:Verifiability")_] For
instance, economic reforms and EU membership introduced stricter requirements
for open bidding and many public monopolies were abolished.[79] Today, Finland
has a very low number of corruption charges; [Transparency
International](/wiki/Transparency_International "Transparency International")
ranks Finland as one of the least corrupt countries in Europe.

In 2008, Transparency International criticized the lack of transparency of the
system of Finnish political finance.[80] According to
[GRECO](/wiki/Group_of_States_Against_Corruption "Group of States Against
Corruption") in 2007, corruption should be taken into account in the Finnish
system of election funds better.[81] [A scandal revolving around campaign
finance of the 2007 parliamentary
elections](/wiki/2007_campaign_finance_scandal_of_Finland "2007 campaign
finance scandal of Finland") broke out in spring 2008. Nine Ministers of
Government submitted incomplete funding reports and even more of the members
of parliament. The law includes no punishment of false funds reports of the
elected politicians.

### Foreign relations[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Finland&action=edit&section=22
"Edit section: Foreign relations")]

Main article: [Foreign relations of
Finland](/wiki/Foreign_relations_of_Finland "Foreign relations of Finland")

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/4/49/Nobel_Peace_Prize_2008_Martti_Ahtisaari.jpg/220px-
Nobel_Peace_Prize_2008_Martti_Ahtisaari.jpg)](/wiki/File:Nobel_Peace_Prize_2008_Martti_Ahtisaari.jpg)

[](/wiki/File:Nobel_Peace_Prize_2008_Martti_Ahtisaari.jpg "Enlarge")

[Martti Ahtisaari](/wiki/Martti_Ahtisaari "Martti Ahtisaari") receiving the
Nobel Peace Prize in 2008

According to the 2012 constitution, the president (currently [Sauli
Niinistö](/wiki/Sauli_Niinist%C3%B6 "Sauli Niinistö")) leads foreign policy in
cooperation with the government, except that the president has no role in EU
affairs.[82]

In 2008, president [Martti Ahtisaari](/wiki/Martti_Ahtisaari "Martti
Ahtisaari") was awarded the [Nobel Peace Prize](/wiki/Nobel_Peace_Prize "Nobel
Peace Prize").[83] Finland was considered a cooperative model state, and
Finland did not oppose proposals for a common EU defence policy.[84] This was
reversed in the 2000s, when Tarja Halonen and [Erkki
Tuomioja](/wiki/Erkki_Tuomioja "Erkki Tuomioja") made Finland's official
policy to resist other EU members' plans for common defence.[84]

### Social security[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Finland&action=edit&section=23
"Edit section: Social security")]

Main article: [Social security in Finland](/wiki/Social_security_in_Finland
"Social security in Finland")

Finland has one of the world's most extensive welfare systems, one that
guarantees decent living conditions for all residents, Finns, and non-
citizens. Since the 1980s the social security has been cut back, but still the
system is one of the most comprehensive in the world. Created almost entirely
during the first three decades after World War II, the social security system
was an outgrowth of the traditional Nordic belief that the state was not
inherently hostile to the well-being of its citizens, but could intervene
benevolently on their behalf. According to some social historians, the basis
of this belief was a relatively benign history that had allowed the gradual
emergence of a free and independent peasantry in the Nordic countries and had
curtailed the dominance of the nobility and the subsequent formation of a
powerful right wing. Finland's history has been harsher than the histories of
the other Nordic countries, but not harsh enough to bar the country from
following their path of social development.[85]

### Military[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Finland&action=edit&section=24 "Edit
section: Military")]

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/1/19/Tracked_transport_vehicle_Sisu_NA_110.JPG/220px-
Tracked_transport_vehicle_Sisu_NA_110.JPG)](/wiki/File:Tracked_transport_vehicle_Sisu_NA_110.JPG)

[](/wiki/File:Tracked_transport_vehicle_Sisu_NA_110.JPG "Enlarge")

[Sisu Nasu](/wiki/Sisu_Nasu "Sisu Nasu") NA-110 tracked transport vehicle of
the Finnish Army. Most conscripts receive training for warfare in winter, and
transport vehicles such as this give mobility in heavy snow.

Main articles: [Finnish Defence Forces](/wiki/Finnish_Defence_Forces "Finnish
Defence Forces") and [Military history of
Finland](/wiki/Military_history_of_Finland "Military history of Finland")

See also: [List of wars involving
Finland](/wiki/List_of_wars_involving_Finland "List of wars involving
Finland")

The Finnish Defence Forces consist of a [cadre](/wiki/En_cadre "En cadre") of
professional soldiers (mainly officers and technical personnel), currently
serving conscripts, and a large reserve. The standard readiness strength is
34,700 people in uniform, of which 25% are professional soldiers. A universal
male [conscription](/wiki/Conscription "Conscription") is in place, under
which all male Finnish nationals above 18 years of age serve for 6 to 12
months of armed service or 12 months of civilian (non-armed) service.
Voluntary post-conscription overseas peacekeeping service is popular, and
troops serve around the world in UN, NATO, and EU missions. Approximately 500
women choose voluntary military service every year.[86] Women are allowed to
serve in all combat arms including front-line infantry and special forces. The
army consists of a highly mobile field army backed up by local defence units.
The army defends the national territory and its military strategy employs the
use of the heavily forested terrain and numerous lakes to wear down an
aggressor, instead of attempting to hold the attacking army on the frontier.

Finnish defence expenditure per capita is one of the highest in the European
Union.[87] The Finnish military doctrine is based on the concept of total
defence. The term total means that all sectors of the government and economy
are involved in the defence planning. The armed forces are under the command
of the [Chief of Defence](/wiki/Chief_of_Defence_\(Finland\) "Chief of Defence
\(Finland\)") (currently General [Jarmo Lindberg](/wiki/Jarmo_Lindberg "Jarmo
Lindberg")), who is directly subordinate to the president in matters related
to military command. The branches of the military are the
[army](/wiki/Finnish_Army "Finnish Army"), the [navy](/wiki/Finnish_Navy
"Finnish Navy"), and the [air force](/wiki/Finnish_Air_Force "Finnish Air
Force"). The [border guard](/wiki/Finnish_Border_Guard "Finnish Border Guard")
is under the Ministry of the Interior but can be incorporated into the Defence
Forces when required for defence readiness.

Even while Finland hasn't joined the [North Atlantic Treaty
Organization](/wiki/North_Atlantic_Treaty_Organization "North Atlantic Treaty
Organization"), the country has joined the [NATO Response
Force](/wiki/NATO_Response_Force "NATO Response Force"), the [EU
Battlegroup](/wiki/EU_Battlegroup "EU Battlegroup"),[_[citation
needed](/wiki/Wikipedia:Citation_needed "Wikipedia:Citation needed")_] the
NATO [Partnership for Peace](/wiki/Partnership_for_Peace "Partnership for
Peace") and in signed a NATO [Memorandum of
Understanding](/wiki/Memorandum_of_Understanding "Memorandum of
Understanding"),[88] thus forming a practical coalition.[18] In 2015, the
Finland-NATO ties were strengthened with a host nation support agreement
allowing assistance from NATO troops in emergency situations.[89] Finland has
been active participant in the Afghanistan and Kosovo.[90][91] Recently
Finland has been more eager to discuss about its current and planned roles in
Syria, Iraq and war against ISIL.[92] On 21 December 2012 Finnish military
officer [Atte Kaleva](/w/index.php?title=Atte_Kaleva&action=edit&redlink=1
"Atte Kaleva \(page does not exist\)") was reported to have been kidnapped and
later released in Yemen for ransom. At first he was reported be a casual
Arabic student, however only later it was published that his studies were
about jihadists, terrorism, and that he was employed by the military.[93][94]
As response to French request for solidarity, Finnish defence minister
commented in November that Finland could and is willing to offer intelligence
support.[95]

In May 2015, Finnish Military sent nearly one million letters to all relevant
males in the country, informing them about their roles in the war effort. It
was globally speculated that Finland was preparing for war—however Finland
claimed that this was a standard procedure, yet something never done before in
Finnish history.[96] Mr Hypponen however said that this is not an isolated
case, but bound to the European security dilemma.[96] The NATO Memorandum of
Understanding signed earlier bestows an obligation e.g. to report on internal
capabilities and the availability thereof to NATO.[88]

## Economy[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Finland&action=edit&section=25 "Edit
section: Economy")]

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/a/ae/Angry_Birds_Land_S%C3%A4rk%C3%A4nniemi_11.jpg/220px-
Angry_Birds_Land_S%C3%A4rk%C3%A4nniemi_11.jpg)](/wiki/File:Angry_Birds_Land_S%C3%A4rk%C3%A4nniemi_11.jpg)

[](/wiki/File:Angry_Birds_Land_S%C3%A4rk%C3%A4nniemi_11.jpg "Enlarge")

[Angry Birds](/wiki/Angry_Birds "Angry Birds"), a mobile phone game developed
in Finland, has become a commercial hit both domestically and internationally.

Main article: [Economy of Finland](/wiki/Economy_of_Finland "Economy of
Finland")

See also: [List of companies of Finland](/wiki/List_of_companies_of_Finland
"List of companies of Finland") and [Helsinki Stock
Exchange](/wiki/Helsinki_Stock_Exchange "Helsinki Stock Exchange")

The economy of Finland has a per capita output equal to that of other European
economies such as those of France, Germany, [Belgium](/wiki/Belgium
"Belgium"), or the UK. The largest sector of the economy is the [service
sector](/wiki/Service_sector "Service sector") at 66% of GDP, followed by
manufacturing and refining at 31%. [Primary
production](/wiki/Primary_sector_of_the_economy "Primary sector of the
economy") represents 2.9%.[97] With respect to [foreign
trade](/wiki/International_trade "International trade"), the key economic
sector is manufacturing. The largest industries in 2007[98] were
[electronics](/wiki/Electronics "Electronics") (22%); machinery, vehicles, and
other engineered metal products (21.1%); forest industry (13%); and chemicals
(11%). The gross domestic product peaked in 2008. As of
2015[[update]](//en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=Finland&action=edit), the
country's economy is at the 2006 level.[99][100]

Finland has significant timber, mineral ([iron](/wiki/Iron "Iron"),
[chromium](/wiki/Chromium "Chromium"), [copper](/wiki/Copper "Copper"),
[nickel](/wiki/Nickel "Nickel"), and [gold](/wiki/Gold "Gold")), and
freshwater resources. [Forestry](/wiki/Forestry "Forestry"), paper factories,
and the [agricultural sector](/wiki/Agriculture "Agriculture") (on which
taxpayers spend[_[clarification needed](/wiki/Wikipedia:Please_clarify
"Wikipedia:Please clarify")_] around 3 billion euros annually) are important
for rural residents so any policy changes affecting these sectors are
politically sensitive for politicians dependent on rural votes. The [Greater
Helsinki](/wiki/Greater_Helsinki "Greater Helsinki") area generates around one
third of Finland's GDP. In a 2004 OECD comparison, high-technology
manufacturing in Finland ranked second largest after Ireland. Knowledge-
intensive services have also resulted in the smallest and slow-growth sectors
– especially agriculture and low-technology manufacturing – being ranked the
second largest after Ireland.[101] The overall short-term outlook was good and
GDP growth has been above that of many EU peers.

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/en/thumb/5/5b/Image_illustrates_GDP_growth_of_Finland.png/220px-
Image_illustrates_GDP_growth_of_Finland.png)](/wiki/File:Image_illustrates_GDP_growth_of_Finland.png)

[](/wiki/File:Image_illustrates_GDP_growth_of_Finland.png "Enlarge")

Finland GDP growth from 2000 till 2013

Finland is highly integrated into the global economy, and international trade
produces one third of GDP. Trade with the European Union makes up 60% of
Finland's total trade. The largest trade flows are with Germany, Russia,
Sweden, the United Kingdom, the United States, the
[Netherlands](/wiki/Netherlands "Netherlands"), and China. Trade policy is
managed by the European Union, where Finland has traditionally been among the
free trade supporters, except for agricultural policy. Finland is the only
Nordic country to have joined the Eurozone.

Finland's climate and soils make growing crops a particular challenge. The
country lies between the latitudes 60°N and 70°N, and it has severe winters
and relatively short growing seasons that are sometimes interrupted by frost.
However, because the Gulf Stream and the North Atlantic Drift Current moderate
the climate, Finland contains half of the world's arable land north of 60°
north latitude. Annual precipitation is usually sufficient, but it occurs
almost exclusively during the winter months, making summer droughts a constant
threat. In response to the climate, farmers have relied on quick-ripening and
frost-resistant varieties of crops, and they have cultivated south-facing
slopes as well as richer bottomlands to ensure production even in years with
summer frosts. Most farmland was originally either forest or swamp, and the
soil has usually required treatment with lime and years of cultivation to
neutralize excess acid and to improve fertility. Irrigation has generally not
been necessary, but drainage systems are often needed to remove excess water.
Finland's agriculture has been efficient and productive—at least when compared
with farming in other European countries.[85]

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/8/85/Euro_accession.svg/220px-
Euro_accession.svg.png)](/wiki/File:Euro_accession.svg)

[](/wiki/File:Euro_accession.svg "Enlarge")

Finland is part of the [Eurozone](/wiki/Eurozone "Eurozone"), the [Schengen
Area](/wiki/Schengen_Area "Schengen Area"), and the EU single market.

Forests play a key role in the country's economy, making it one of the world's
leading wood producers and providing raw materials at competitive prices for
the crucial wood-processing industries. As in agriculture, the government has
long played a leading role in forestry, regulating tree cutting, sponsoring
technical improvements, and establishing long-term plans to ensure that the
country's forests continue to supply the wood-processing industries. To
maintain the country's comparative advantage in forest products, Finnish
authorities moved to raise lumber output toward the country's ecological
limits. In 1984, the government published the Forest 2000 plan, drawn up by
the Ministry of Agriculture and Forestry. The plan aimed at increasing forest
harvests by about 3% per year, while conserving forestland for recreation and
other uses.[85]

Private sector employees amount to 1.8 million, out of which around a third
with tertiary education. The average cost of a private sector employee per
hour was 25.1 euros in 2004.[102] As of
2008[[update]](//en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=Finland&action=edit),
average purchasing power-adjusted income levels are similar to those of Italy,
Sweden, Germany, and France.[103] In 2006, 62% of the workforce worked for
enterprises with less than 250 employees and they accounted for 49% of total
business turnover and had the strongest rate of growth.[104] The female
employment rate is high. Gender segregation between male-dominated professions
and female-dominated professions is higher than in the US.[105] The proportion
of part-time workers was one of the lowest in OECD in 1999.[105] In 2013, the
10 largest private sector employers in Finland were [Itella](/wiki/Itella
"Itella"), [Nokia](/wiki/Nokia "Nokia"), [OP-Pohjola](/wiki/OP_Financial_Group
"OP Financial Group"), [ISS](/wiki/ISS_A/S "ISS A/S"), [VR](/wiki/VR_Group "VR
Group"), [Kesko](/wiki/Kesko "Kesko"), [UPM-Kymmene](/wiki/UPM-Kymmene "UPM-
Kymmene"), [YIT](/wiki/YIT "YIT"), [Metso](/wiki/Metso "Metso"), and
[Nordea](/wiki/Nordea "Nordea").[106]

The unemployment rate was 9.4% in 2015, having risen from 8.7% in 2014.[107]
Youth unemployment rate rose from 16.5% in 2007 to 20.5% in 2014.[108] A fifth
of residents are outside the job market at the age of 50 and less than a third
are working at the age of 61.[109] As of today, nearly one million people are
living with minimal wages or unemployed not enough to cover their costs of
living.[110]

As of
2006[[update]](//en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=Finland&action=edit), 2.4
million households reside in Finland. The average size is 2.1 persons; 40% of
households consist of a single person, 32% two persons and 28% three or more
persons. Residential buildings total 1.2 million, and the average residential
space is 38 square metres (410 sq ft) per person. The average residential
property without land costs 1,187 euro per sq metre and residential land 8.6
euro per sq metre. 74% of households had a car. There are 2.5 million cars and
0.4 million other vehicles.[111]

Around 92% have a mobile phone and 83.5% (2009) [Internet connection at
home](/wiki/List_of_countries_by_number_of_Internet_users "List of countries
by number of Internet users"). The average total household consumption was
20,000 euro, out of which housing consisted of about 5,500 euro, transport
about 3,000 euro, food and beverages excluding alcoholic beverages at around
2,500 euro, and recreation and culture at around 2,000 euro.[112] According to
Invest in Finland, private consumption grew by 3% in 2006 and consumer trends
included durables, high quality products, and spending on well-being.[113]

### Energy[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Finland&action=edit&section=26 "Edit
section: Energy")]

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/5/5a/EPR_OLK3_TVO_fotomont_2_Vogelperspektive.jpg/220px-
EPR_OLK3_TVO_fotomont_2_Vogelperspektive.jpg)](/wiki/File:EPR_OLK3_TVO_fotomont_2_Vogelperspektive.jpg)

[](/wiki/File:EPR_OLK3_TVO_fotomont_2_Vogelperspektive.jpg "Enlarge")

The two existing units of the [Olkiluoto Nuclear Power
Plant](/wiki/Olkiluoto_Nuclear_Power_Plant "Olkiluoto Nuclear Power Plant").
On the far left is a visualization of a third unit, which, when completed,
will become Finland's fifth commercial nuclear reactor.[114]

See also: [Nordic energy market](/wiki/Nordic_energy_market "Nordic energy
market") and [Nuclear power in Finland](/wiki/Nuclear_power_in_Finland
"Nuclear power in Finland")

Anyone can enter the free and largely privately owned financial and physical
[Nordic energy markets](/wiki/Nordic_energy_market "Nordic energy market")
traded in [NASDAQ OMX Commodities Europe](/wiki/NASDAQ_OMX_Commodities_Europe
"NASDAQ OMX Commodities Europe") and [Nord Pool Spot](/wiki/Nord_Pool_Spot
"Nord Pool Spot") exchanges, which have provided competitive prices compared
with other EU countries. As of
2007[[update]](//en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=Finland&action=edit),
Finland has roughly the lowest industrial electricity prices in the
[EU-15](/wiki/EU-15 "EU-15") (equal to France).[115]

In 2006, the energy market was around 90 terawatt hours and the peak demand
around 15 [gigawatts](/wiki/Gigawatt "Gigawatt") in winter. This means that
the [energy consumption per
capita](/wiki/List_of_countries_by_energy_consumption_per_capita "List of
countries by energy consumption per capita") is around 7.2 tons of oil
equivalent per year. Industry and construction consumed 51% of total
consumption, a relatively high figure reflecting Finland's
industries.[116][117] Finland's [hydrocarbon](/wiki/Hydrocarbon "Hydrocarbon")
resources are limited to [peat](/wiki/Peat "Peat") and wood. About 10–15% of
the electricity is produced by [hydropower](/wiki/Hydropower
"Hydropower"),[118] which is low compared with more mountainous Sweden or
Norway. In 2008, [renewable energy](/wiki/Renewable_energy "Renewable energy")
(mainly hydropower and various forms of wood energy) was high at 31% compared
with the EU average of 10.3% in final energy consumption.[119]

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/en/thumb/b/b8/Statistics_of_the_energy_supply_in_Finland.jpg/220px-
Statistics_of_the_energy_supply_in_Finland.jpg)](/wiki/File:Statistics_of_the_energy_supply_in_Finland.jpg)

[](/wiki/File:Statistics_of_the_energy_supply_in_Finland.jpg "Enlarge")

Supply and total consumption of electricity in Finland[120]

Finland has four privately owned nuclear reactors producing 18% of the
country's energy[121] and one research reactor at the
[Otaniemi](/wiki/Otaniemi "Otaniemi") campus. The fifth [AREVA](/wiki/AREVA
"AREVA")-[Siemens](/wiki/Siemens_AG "Siemens AG")-built reactor—the world's
largest at 1600 [MWe](/wiki/MWe "MWe") and a focal point of Europe's nuclear
industry—has faced many delays and is currently scheduled to be operational by
2018–2020, a decade after the original planned opening.[122] A varying amount
(5–17%) of electricity has been imported from Russia (at around 3 gigawatt
power line capacity), Sweden and Norway.

Energy companies are about to increase nuclear power production, as in July
2010 the Finnish parliament granted permits for additional two new reactors.

### Transport[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Finland&action=edit&section=27 "Edit
section: Transport")]

Main article: [Transport in Finland](/wiki/Transport_in_Finland "Transport in
Finland")

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/c/cd/Kontio_towing.jpg/220px-
Kontio_towing.jpg)](/wiki/File:Kontio_towing.jpg)

[](/wiki/File:Kontio_towing.jpg "Enlarge")

[Icebreakers](/wiki/Icebreaker "Icebreaker") enable shipping even during
severe winters.

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/2/2d/I1949_Bf_B%C3%B6le%2C_Sr2_3220.jpg/220px-I1949_Bf_B%C3%B6le%2C_Sr2_3220.jpg)](/wiki/File:I1949_Bf_B%C3%B6le,_Sr2_3220.jpg)

[](/wiki/File:I1949_Bf_B%C3%B6le,_Sr2_3220.jpg "Enlarge")

The state-owned [VR Group](/wiki/VR_Group "VR Group") operates a railway
network serving all major cities.

The extensive road system is utilized by most internal cargo and passenger
traffic. The annual state operated road network expenditure of around 1
billion euro is paid with vehicle and fuel taxes which amount to around 1.5
billion euro and 1 billion euro.

The main international passenger gateway is [Helsinki
Airport](/wiki/Helsinki_Airport "Helsinki Airport") with about 17 million
passengers in 2016. [Oulu Airport](/wiki/Oulu_Airport "Oulu Airport") is the
second largest, whilst another [25 airports](/wiki/List_of_airports_in_Finland
"List of airports in Finland") have scheduled passenger services.[123] The
Helsinki Airport-based [Finnair](/wiki/Finnair "Finnair"), [Blue1](/wiki/Blue1
"Blue1"), and [Nordic Regional Airlines](/wiki/Nordic_Regional_Airlines
"Nordic Regional Airlines"), [Norwegian Air
Shuttle](/wiki/Norwegian_Air_Shuttle "Norwegian Air Shuttle") sell air
services both domestically and internationally. Helsinki has an optimal
location for [great circle](/wiki/Great_circle "Great circle") (i.e. the
shortest and most efficient) routes between Western Europe and the Far East.

Despite low population density, the Government spends annually around 350
million euro in maintaining 5,865 kilometres (3,644 mi) of railway tracks.
Rail transport is handled by state owned [VR Group](/wiki/VR_Group "VR
Group"), which has 5% passenger market share (out of which 80% are urban trips
in Greater Helsinki) and 25% cargo market share.[124] Since 12 December 2010,
[Karelian Trains](/wiki/Karelian_Trains "Karelian Trains"), a joint venture
between [Russian Railways](/wiki/Russian_Railways "Russian Railways") and [VR
(Finnish Railways)](/wiki/VR_Group "VR Group"), has been running [Alstom
Pendolino](/wiki/Karelian_Trains_Class_Sm6 "Karelian Trains Class Sm6")
operated high-speed services between Saint Petersburg's
[Finlyandsky](/wiki/Finlyandsky_Rail_Terminal "Finlyandsky Rail Terminal") and
Helsinki's [Central](/wiki/Helsinki_Central_railway_station "Helsinki Central
railway station") railway stations. These services are branded as "Allegro"
trains. The journey from Helsinki to [Saint Petersburg](/wiki/Saint_Petersburg
"Saint Petersburg") takes only three and a half hours.

The majority of international cargo utilizes ports. Port logistics prices are
low. [Vuosaari Harbour](/wiki/Vuosaari_Harbour "Vuosaari Harbour") in Helsinki
is the largest container port after completion in 2008 and others include
[Kotka](/wiki/Kotka "Kotka"), [Hamina](/wiki/Hamina "Hamina"),
[Hanko](/wiki/Hanko "Hanko"), [Pori](/wiki/Pori "Pori"),
[Rauma](/wiki/Rauma,_Finland "Rauma, Finland"), and [Oulu](/wiki/Oulu "Oulu").
There is passenger traffic from Helsinki and Turku, which have ferry
connections to [Tallinn](/wiki/Tallinn "Tallinn"), [Mariehamn](/wiki/Mariehamn
"Mariehamn"), and [Stockholm](/wiki/Stockholm "Stockholm"). The Helsinki-
Tallinn route, one of the busiest passenger sea routes in the world, has also
been served by a helicopter line.

### Industry[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Finland&action=edit&section=28 "Edit
section: Industry")]

Main article: [Economy of Finland](/wiki/Economy_of_Finland "Economy of
Finland")

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/3/37/NokiaHeadquartersByPollo.JPG/220px-
NokiaHeadquartersByPollo.JPG)](/wiki/File:NokiaHeadquartersByPollo.JPG)

[](/wiki/File:NokiaHeadquartersByPollo.JPG "Enlarge")

Former headquarters of electronics corporation [Nokia](/wiki/Nokia "Nokia") in
[Espoo](/wiki/Espoo "Espoo").

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/b/b7/Finnair%2C_Airbus_A350-900_OH-
LWC_NRT_%2830222794141%29.jpg/220px-Finnair%2C_Airbus_A350-900_OH-
LWC_NRT_%2830222794141%29.jpg)](/wiki/File:Finnair,_Airbus_A350-900_OH-
LWC_NRT_\(30222794141\).jpg)

[](/wiki/File:Finnair,_Airbus_A350-900_OH-LWC_NRT_\(30222794141\).jpg
"Enlarge")

[Finnair](/wiki/Finnair "Finnair") [Airbus A350 XWB](/wiki/Airbus_A350_XWB
"Airbus A350 XWB").

Finland was rapidly industrialized after World War II, achieving GDP per
capita levels equal to that of Japan or the UK in the beginning of the 1970s.
Initially, most development was based on two broad groups of export-led
industries, the "metal industry" (_metalliteollisuus_) and "forest industry"
(_metsäteollisuus_). The "metal industry" includes shipbuilding, metalworking,
the car industry, engineered products such as motors and electronics, and
production of metals (steel, copper and chromium). The world's biggest [cruise
ships](/wiki/Cruise_ship "Cruise ship") are built in Finnish shipyards. The
"forest industry" (_metsäteollisuus_) includes forestry, timber, pulp and
paper, and is a logical development based on Finland's extensive forest
resources (77% of the area is covered by forest, most of it in renewable use).
In the [pulp and paper industry](/wiki/Pulp_and_paper_industry "Pulp and paper
industry"), many of the largest companies are based in Finland
([Ahlstrom](/wiki/Ahlstrom "Ahlstrom"), [Metsä Board](/wiki/Mets%C3%A4_Board
"Metsä Board"), and [UPM](/wiki/UPM_\(company\) "UPM \(company\)")). However,
the Finnish economy has diversified, with expansion into fields such as
electronics (e.g. [Nokia](/wiki/Nokia "Nokia")), metrology
([Vaisala](/wiki/Vaisala "Vaisala")), transport fuels ([Neste](/wiki/Neste
"Neste")), chemicals ([Kemira](/wiki/Kemira "Kemira")), engineering consulting
([Pöyry](/wiki/P%C3%B6yry "Pöyry")), and information technology (e.g. [Rovio
Entertainment](/wiki/Rovio_Entertainment "Rovio Entertainment"), known for
[Angry Birds](/wiki/Angry_Birds "Angry Birds")), and is no longer dominated by
the two sectors of metal and forest industry. Likewise, the structure has
changed, with the service sector growing, with manufacturing reducing in
importance; agriculture is only a minor part. Despite this, production for
export is still more prominent than in Western Europe, thus making Finland
more vulnerable to global economic trends.

In an [Economist Intelligence Unit](/wiki/Economist_Intelligence_Unit
"Economist Intelligence Unit") report released in September 2011, Finland
clinched the second place after the United States on Benchmarking IT Industry
Competitiveness 2011 which scored on 6 key indicators: overall business
environment, technology infrastructure, human capital, legal framework, public
support for industry development, and research and development landscape.[125]

### Public policy[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Finland&action=edit&section=29
"Edit section: Public policy")]

See also: [Nordic model](/wiki/Nordic_model "Nordic model")

Finnish politicians have often emulated other Nordics and the Nordic
model.[126] Nordics have been free-trading and relatively welcoming to skilled
migrants for over a century, though in Finland [immigration](/wiki/Immigration
"Immigration") is relatively new. The level of protection in commodity trade
has been low, except for agricultural products.[126]

Finland has top levels of economic freedom in many areas.[_[clarification
needed](/wiki/Wikipedia:Please_clarify "Wikipedia:Please clarify")_] Finland
is ranked 16th in the 2008 global [Index of Economic
Freedom](/wiki/Index_of_Economic_Freedom "Index of Economic Freedom") and 9th
in Europe.[127] While the manufacturing sector is thriving, the OECD points
out that the service sector would benefit substantially from policy
improvements.[128]

The 2007 [IMD](/wiki/International_Institute_for_Management_Development
"International Institute for Management Development") World Competitiveness
Yearbook ranked Finland 17th most [competitive](/wiki/Competitiveness
"Competitiveness").[129] The [World Economic Forum](/wiki/World_Economic_Forum
"World Economic Forum") 2008 index ranked Finland the 6th most
competitive.[130] In both indicators, Finland's performance was next to
Germany, and significantly higher than most European countries. In the
Business competitiveness index 2007–2008 Finland ranked third in the world.

Economists attribute much growth to reforms in the product markets. According
to the OECD, only four [EU-15](/wiki/EU-15 "EU-15") countries have less
regulated [product markets](/wiki/Product_market "Product market") (UK,
Ireland, Denmark and Sweden) and only one has less regulated [financial
markets](/wiki/Financial_market "Financial market") (Denmark). Nordic
countries were pioneers in liberalizing energy, postal, and other markets in
Europe.[126] The legal system is clear and business bureaucracy less than most
countries.[127] Property rights are well protected and contractual agreements
are strictly honoured.[127] Finland is rated the least corrupt country in the
world in the [Corruption Perceptions Index](/wiki/Corruption_Perceptions_Index
"Corruption Perceptions Index")[131] and 13th in the [Ease of doing business
index](/wiki/Ease_of_doing_business_index "Ease of doing business index").
This indicates exceptional ease in cross-border trading (5th), contract
enforcement (7th), business closure (5th), tax payment (83rd), and low worker
hardship (127th).[132]

Finnish law [forces all workers to obey the national
contracts](/wiki/Universal_validity_of_collective_labour_agreements "Universal
validity of collective labour agreements") that are drafted every few years
for each profession and seniority level. The agreement becomes universally
enforceable provided that more than 50% of the employees support it, in
practice by being a member of a relevant trade union. The unionization rate is
high (70%), especially in the middle class
([AKAVA](/wiki/Confederation_of_Unions_for_Academic_Professionals_in_Finland
"Confederation of Unions for Academic Professionals in Finland")—80%). A lack
of a national agreement in an industry is considered an exception.[101][126]

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/4/46/Ecker%C3%B6_Line_-
_Finlandia.JPG/220px-Ecker%C3%B6_Line_-
_Finlandia.JPG)](/wiki/File:Ecker%C3%B6_Line_-_Finlandia.JPG)

[](/wiki/File:Ecker%C3%B6_Line_-_Finlandia.JPG "Enlarge")

[Eckerö Line](/wiki/Ecker%C3%B6_Line "Eckerö Line") Finlandia, one of the
[Baltic Sea](/wiki/Baltic_Sea "Baltic Sea") cruiseferries

In 2005, Finnish tourism grossed over €6.7 billion with a 5% increase from the
previous year. Much of the sudden growth can be attributed to the
[globalisation](/wiki/Globalisation "Globalisation") and modernisation of the
country as well as a rise in positive publicity and awareness. There are many
attractions in Finland which attracted over 8 million visitors in 2013.

The Finnish landscape is covered with thick [pine](/wiki/Pine "Pine") forests
and rolling hills, and complemented with a labyrinth of lakes and
[inlets](/wiki/Inlet "Inlet"). Much of Finland is pristine and virgin as it
contains 40 national parks from the Southern shores of the [Gulf of
Finland](/wiki/Gulf_of_Finland "Gulf of Finland") to the high
[fells](/wiki/Fell "Fell") of Lapland. Finland also has urbanised regions with
many cultural events and activities.

[Commercial cruises](/wiki/Baltic_Sea_cruiseferries "Baltic Sea
cruiseferries") between major coastal and port cities in the Baltic region,
including Helsinki, [Turku](/wiki/Turku "Turku"), [Tallinn](/wiki/Tallinn
"Tallinn"), [Stockholm](/wiki/Stockholm "Stockholm"), and
[Travemünde](/wiki/Travem%C3%BCnde "Travemünde"), play a significant role in
the local tourism industry. Finland is locally regarded as the home of Saint
Nicholas or [Santa Claus](/wiki/Santa_Claus "Santa Claus"), living in the
northern Lapland region.[133] Above the [Arctic Circle](/wiki/Arctic_Circle
"Arctic Circle"), in midwinter, there is a [polar night](/wiki/Polar_night
"Polar night"), a period when the sun does not rise for days or weeks, or even
months, and correspondingly, [midnight sun](/wiki/Midnight_sun "Midnight sun")
in the summer, with no sunset even at midnight (for up to 73 consecutive days,
at the northernmost point). Lapland is so far north that the [Aurora
Borealis](/wiki/Aurora_Borealis "Aurora Borealis"),
[fluorescence](/wiki/Fluorescence "Fluorescence") in the high atmosphere due
to [solar wind](/wiki/Solar_wind "Solar wind"), is seen regularly in the fall,
winter, and spring.

Outdoor activities range from [Nordic skiing](/wiki/Nordic_skiing "Nordic
skiing"), golf, fishing, [yachting](/wiki/Yachting "Yachting"), lake cruises,
hiking, and [kayaking](/wiki/Kayaking "Kayaking"), among many others. Wildlife
is abundant in Finland. [Bird-watching](/wiki/Bird-watching "Bird-watching")
is popular for those fond of avifauna, however hunting is also popular.
[Elk](/wiki/Moose "Moose") and [hare](/wiki/Hare "Hare") are common game in
Finland. [Olavinlinna](/wiki/Olavinlinna "Olavinlinna") in
[Savonlinna](/wiki/Savonlinna "Savonlinna") hosts the annual [Savonlinna Opera
Festival](/wiki/Savonlinna_Opera_Festival "Savonlinna Opera Festival").

## Demographics[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Finland&action=edit&section=31 "Edit
section: Demographics")]

Main article: [Demographics of Finland](/wiki/Demographics_of_Finland
"Demographics of Finland")

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/7/71/Population_pyramid_finland_2013.png/170px-
Population_pyramid_finland_2013.png)](/wiki/File:Population_pyramid_finland_2013.png)

[](/wiki/File:Population_pyramid_finland_2013.png "Enlarge")

Population of Finland by age group and sex in 2013

The population of Finland is currently about 5.5 million inhabitants and is
aging with the [birth rate](/wiki/Birth_rate "Birth rate") at 10.42 births per
1,000 population per year, or a [fertility rate](/wiki/Fertility_rate
"Fertility rate") of 1.8 with a median age of 42.7 years. Approximately half
of voters are estimated to be over 50 years old.[134][48][135][8] Finland has
an average population density of 18 inhabitants per square kilometre. This is
the third-lowest population density of any European country, behind those of
Norway and [Iceland](/wiki/Iceland "Iceland"), and the lowest population
density in the EU. Finland's population has always been concentrated in the
southern parts of the country, a phenomenon that became even more pronounced
during 20th-century urbanisation. The largest cities in Finland are those of
the [Greater Helsinki](/wiki/Greater_Helsinki "Greater Helsinki")
[metropolitan area](/wiki/Metropolitan_area "Metropolitan
area")—[Helsinki](/wiki/Helsinki "Helsinki"), [Espoo](/wiki/Espoo "Espoo"),
and [Vantaa](/wiki/Vantaa "Vantaa"). Other cities with population over 100,000
are [Tampere](/wiki/Tampere "Tampere"), [Turku](/wiki/Turku "Turku"),
[Oulu](/wiki/Oulu "Oulu"), [Jyväskylä](/wiki/Jyv%C3%A4skyl%C3%A4 "Jyväskylä"),
[Kuopio](/wiki/Kuopio "Kuopio"), and [Lahti](/wiki/Lahti "Lahti").

As of 2014, there were 322,700 people with a foreign background living in
Finland (5.9% of the population), most of whom are from Russia, Estonia,
Somalia, Iraq and Yugoslavia.[136] The children of foreigners are not
automatically given Finnish citizenship, as Finnish nationality law practices
and maintain _[jus sanguinis](/wiki/Jus_sanguinis "Jus sanguinis")_ policy
where only children born to at least one Finnish parent are granted
citizenship. If they are born in Finland and cannot get citizenship of any
other country, they become citizens.[137] Additionally, certain persons of
Finnish descent who reside in countries that were once part of [Soviet
Union](/wiki/Soviet_Union "Soviet Union"), retain the [right of
return](/wiki/Right_of_return "Right of return"), a right to establish
permanent residency in the country, which would eventually entitle them to
qualify for citizenship.[138]
