### Religion[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Finland&action=edit&section=33 "Edit
section: Religion")]

Main article: [Religion in Finland](/wiki/Religion_in_Finland "Religion in
Finland")

**Religion in Finland[139]**  
---  
year | Evangelical Lutheran Church of Finland | Finnish Orthodox Church | Other | No religious affiliation  
1950 | 95.0% | 1.7% | 0.5% | 2.8%  
1980 | 90.3% | 1.1% | 0.7% | 7.8%  
1990 | 87.8% | 1.1% | 0.9% | 10.2%  
2000 | 85.1% | 1.1% | 1.1% | 12.7%  
2010 | 78.3% | 1.1% | 1.4% | 19.2%  
2014 | 73.9% | 1.1% | 1.6% | 23.5%  
2015 | 73.0% | 1.1% | 1.6% | 24.3%  
2016 | 72.0% | 1.1% | 1.6% | 25.3%  
  
[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/1/15/Catedral_Luterana_de_Helsinki%2C_Finlandia%2C_2012-08-14%2C_DD_01.JPG/220px-
Catedral_Luterana_de_Helsinki%2C_Finlandia%2C_2012-08-14%2C_DD_01.JPG)](/wiki/File:Catedral_Luterana_de_Helsinki,_Finlandia,_2012-08-14,_DD_01.JPG)

[](/wiki/File:Catedral_Luterana_de_Helsinki,_Finlandia,_2012-08-14,_DD_01.JPG
"Enlarge")

The Evangelical Lutheran [Helsinki Cathedral](/wiki/Helsinki_Cathedral
"Helsinki Cathedral")

With slightly under four million members, the Evangelical Lutheran Church of
Finland is one of the largest Lutheran churches in the world and is also by
far Finland's largest religious body; at the end of 2016, 71.9% of Finns were
members of the church.[140] 7 out of 10 Finns are members of the [Evangelical
Lutheran Church of Finland](/wiki/Evangelical_Lutheran_Church_of_Finland
"Evangelical Lutheran Church of Finland"), which was
[disestablished](/wiki/Separation_of_church_and_state "Separation of church
and state") in 1869 by the Church Act. It was the first state church to be
disestablished in the [Nordic countries](/wiki/Nordic_countries "Nordic
countries"), to be followed by the [Church of Sweden](/wiki/Church_of_Sweden
"Church of Sweden") in 2000. The Evangelical Lutheran Church of Finland sees
its share of the country's population declining by roughly one percent
annually in recent years.[139] The decline has been due to both church
membership resignations and falling baptism rates.[141][142] The second
largest group, accounting for 25.3% of the population[139] in 2016, has no
religious affiliation. The irreligious group rose quickly from just below 13%
in the year 2000. A small minority belongs to the [Finnish Orthodox
Church](/wiki/Finnish_Orthodox_Church "Finnish Orthodox Church") (1.1%). Other
[Protestant](/wiki/Protestant "Protestant") denominations and the [Roman
Catholic Church](/wiki/Roman_Catholic_Church "Roman Catholic Church") are
significantly smaller, as are the [Muslim](/wiki/Muslim "Muslim"),
[Jewish](/wiki/Jewish "Jewish"), and other non-Christian communities
(totalling 1.6%). The main Lutheran and Orthodox churches are [national
churches](/wiki/National_church "National church") of Finland with special
roles such as in state ceremonies and schools.[143]

In 1869, Finland was the first Nordic country to
[disestablish](/wiki/Disestablishment "Disestablishment") [its Evangelical
Lutheran church](/wiki/Evangelical_Lutheran_Church_of_Finland "Evangelical
Lutheran Church of Finland") by introducing the Church Act. Although the
church still maintains a special relationship with the state, it is not
described as a [state religion](/wiki/State_religion "State religion") in the
[Finnish Constitution](/wiki/Constitution_of_Finland "Constitution of
Finland") or other laws passed by the [Finnish
Parliament](/wiki/Finnish_Parliament "Finnish Parliament").[144] Finland's
state church was the [Church of Sweden](/wiki/Church_of_Sweden "Church of
Sweden") until 1809. As an autonomous Grand Duchy under Russia 1809–1917,
Finland retained the Lutheran State Church system, and a state church separate
from Sweden, later named the [Evangelical Lutheran Church of
Finland](/wiki/Evangelical_Lutheran_Church_of_Finland "Evangelical Lutheran
Church of Finland"), was established. It was detached from the state as a
separate judicial entity when the new church law came to force in 1869. After
Finland had gained independence in 1917, religious freedom was declared in the
constitution of 1919 and a separate law on religious freedom in 1922. Through
this arrangement, the Evangelical Lutheran Church of Finland lost its position
as a state church but gained a constitutional status as a national church
alongside the [Finnish Orthodox Church](/wiki/Finnish_Orthodox_Church "Finnish
Orthodox Church"), whose position however is not codified in the constitution.

In 2016, 69.3% of Finnish children were [baptized](/wiki/Baptism
"Baptism")[145] and 82.3% were
[confirmed](/wiki/Confirmation_\(Lutheran_Church\) "Confirmation \(Lutheran
Church\)") in 2012 at the age of 15,[146] and over 90% of the funerals are
Christian. However, the majority of Lutherans attend church only for special
occasions like Christmas ceremonies, weddings, and funerals. The Lutheran
Church estimates that approximately 1.8% of its members attend church services
weekly.[147] The average number of church visits per year by church members is
approximately two.[148]

According to a 2010 [Eurobarometer](/wiki/Eurobarometer "Eurobarometer") poll,
33% of Finnish citizens responded that "they believe there is a God"; 42%
answered that "they believe there is some sort of spirit or life force"; and
22% that "they do not believe there is any sort of spirit, God, or life
force".[149] According to ISSP survey data (2008), 8% consider themselves
"highly religious", and 31% "moderately religious". In the same survey, 28%
reported themselves as "agnostic" and 29% as "non-religious".[150]

### Health[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Finland&action=edit&section=34 "Edit
section: Health")]

Main article: [Healthcare in Finland](/wiki/Healthcare_in_Finland "Healthcare
in Finland")

[Life expectancy](/wiki/Life_expectancy "Life expectancy") has increased from
71 years for men and 79 years for women in 1990 to 78 years for men and 84
years for women in 2012.[151] The under-five mortality rate has decreased from
51 per 1,000 live births in 1950 to 3 per 1,000 live births in 2012 ranking
Finland's rate among the lowest in the world.[152][153] The [fertility
rate](/wiki/Fertility_rate "Fertility rate") in 2014 stood at 1.71 children
born/per woman and has been below [the replacement rate](/wiki/Sub-
replacement_fertility "Sub-replacement fertility") of 2.1 since 1969.[154]
With a low birth rate women also become mothers at a later age, the mean age
at first live birth being 28.6 in 2014.[154]

There has been a slight increase or no change in welfare and health
inequalities between population groups in the 21st century. Lifestyle-related
diseases are on the rise. More than half a million Finns suffer from diabetes,
type 1 diabetes being globally the most common in Finland. Many children are
diagnosed with type 2 diabetes. The number of musculoskeletal diseases and
cancers are increasing, although the cancer prognosis has improved. Allergies
and dementia are also growing health problems in Finland. One of the most
common reasons for work disability are due to mental disorders, in particular
depression.[155]

There are 307 residents for each doctor.[156] About 19% of health care is
funded directly by households and 77% by taxation.

A recent study by The Lancet medical journal found that Finland has the lowest
stillbirth rate out of 193 countries, including the UK, France, and New
Zealand.[157] In April 2012, Finland was ranked 2nd in Gross National
Happiness in a report published by The Earth Institute.[158]

### Education and
science[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Finland&action=edit&section=35 "Edit
section: Education and science")]

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/d/d4/Helsinki_University_of_Technology_auditorium.jpg/220px-
Helsinki_University_of_Technology_auditorium.jpg)](/wiki/File:Helsinki_University_of_Technology_auditorium.jpg)

[](/wiki/File:Helsinki_University_of_Technology_auditorium.jpg "Enlarge")

Auditorium in [Aalto University](/wiki/Aalto_University "Aalto University")'s
main building, designed by [Alvar Aalto](/wiki/Alvar_Aalto "Alvar Aalto").

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/1/1e/Torvisen_kansakoulu_1924-26.jpg/220px-
Torvisen_kansakoulu_1924-26.jpg)](/wiki/File:Torvisen_kansakoulu_1924-26.jpg)

[](/wiki/File:Torvisen_kansakoulu_1924-26.jpg "Enlarge")

Pupils at the school of Torvinen in Sodankylä, Finland, in the 1920s

Main article: [Education in Finland](/wiki/Education_in_Finland "Education in
Finland")

See also: [List of universities in
Finland](/wiki/List_of_universities_in_Finland "List of universities in
Finland") and [List of schools in Finland](/wiki/List_of_schools_in_Finland
"List of schools in Finland")

Most pre-tertiary education is arranged at municipal level. Even though many
or most schools were started as private schools, today only around 3 percent
of students are enrolled in private schools (mostly specialist language and
international schools), much less than in Sweden and most other developed
countries.[159] Pre-school education is rare compared with other EU countries
and formal education is usually started at the age of 7. Primary school takes
normally six years and lower secondary school three years. Most schools are
managed by municipal officials.

The flexible curriculum is set by the Ministry of Education and the Education
Board. Education is compulsory between the ages of 7 and 16. After lower
secondary school, graduates may either enter the workforce directly, or apply
to trade schools or [gymnasiums](/wiki/Gymnasium_\(school\) "Gymnasium
\(school\)") (upper secondary schools). Trade schools offer a [vocational
education](/wiki/Vocational_education "Vocational education"): approximately
40% of an age group choose this path after the lower secondary school.[160]
Academically oriented gymnasiums have higher entrance requirements and
specifically prepare for [Abitur](/wiki/Abitur "Abitur") and tertiary
education. Graduation from either formally qualifies for tertiary education.

In tertiary education, two mostly separate and non-interoperating sectors are
found: the profession-oriented polytechnics and the research-oriented
universities. Education is free and living expenses are to a large extent
financed by the government through [student benefits](/wiki/Student_benefit
"Student benefit"). There are 20 universities and 30 polytechnics in the
country. The [University of Helsinki](/wiki/University_of_Helsinki "University
of Helsinki") is ranked 75th in the Top University Ranking of 2010.[161] The
[World Economic Forum](/wiki/World_Economic_Forum "World Economic Forum")
ranks Finland's tertiary education No. 1 in the world.[162] Around 33% of
residents have a tertiary degree, similar to Nordics and more than in most
other OECD countries except Canada (44%), United States (38%) and Japan
(37%).[163] The proportion of foreign students is 3% of all tertiary
enrollments, one of the lowest in OECD, while in advanced programs it is 7.3%,
still below OECD average 16.5%.[164]

More than 30% of tertiary graduates are in science-related fields. Forest
improvement, materials research, environmental sciences, neural networks, low-
temperature physics, brain research, biotechnology, genetic technology, and
communications showcase fields of study where Finnish researchers have had a
significant impact.[165]

Finland has a long tradition of adult education, and by the 1980s nearly one
million Finns were receiving some kind of instruction each year. Forty percent
of them did so for professional reasons. Adult education appeared in a number
of forms, such as secondary evening schools, civic and workers' institutes,
study centres, vocational course centres, and folk high schools. Study centres
allowed groups to follow study plans of their own making, with educational and
financial assistance provided by the state. [Folk high
schools](/wiki/Folk_high_school "Folk high school") are a distinctly Nordic
institution. Originating in Denmark in the nineteenth century, folk high
schools became common throughout the region. Adults of all ages could stay at
them for several weeks and take courses in subjects that ranged from
handicrafts to economics.[85]

Finland is highly productive in scientific research. In 2005, Finland had the
fourth most scientific publications per capita of the OECD countries.[166] In
2007, 1,801 patents were filed in Finland.[167]

In addition, 38 percent of Finland's population has a university or [college
degree](/wiki/College_degree "College degree"), which is among the highest
percentages in the [world](/wiki/World "World").[168][169]

In 2010 a new law was enacted considering the universities, which defined that
there are 16 of them as they were excluded from the public sector to be
autonomous legal and financial entities, however enjoying special status in
the legislation.[170] As result many former state institutions were driven to
collect funding from private sector contributions and partnerships. The change
caused deep rooted discussions among the academic circles.[171]

English language is important in Finnish education. There are a number of
degree programs that are taught in English, which attracts thousands of degree
and exchange students every year.

## Culture[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Finland&action=edit&section=36 "Edit
section: Culture")]

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/0/06/Mikael_Agricola_by_Albert_Edelfelt.jpg/170px-
Mikael_Agricola_by_Albert_Edelfelt.jpg)](/wiki/File:Mikael_Agricola_by_Albert_Edelfelt.jpg)

[](/wiki/File:Mikael_Agricola_by_Albert_Edelfelt.jpg "Enlarge")

[Mikael Agricola](/wiki/Mikael_Agricola "Mikael Agricola"), a Lutheran
Protestant reformer and the father of the Finnish written language.

Main article: [Culture of Finland](/wiki/Culture_of_Finland "Culture of
Finland")

### Literature[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Finland&action=edit&section=37 "Edit
section: Literature")]

Main article: [Finnish literature](/wiki/Finnish_literature "Finnish
literature")

Written Finnish could be said to have existed since [Mikael
Agricola](/wiki/Mikael_Agricola "Mikael Agricola") translated the [New
Testament](/wiki/New_Testament "New Testament") into Finnish during the
[Protestant Reformation](/wiki/Protestant_Reformation "Protestant
Reformation"), but few notable works of literature were written until the
nineteenth century and the beginning of a Finnish national [Romantic
Movement](/wiki/Romanticism "Romanticism"). This prompted [Elias
Lönnrot](/wiki/Elias_L%C3%B6nnrot "Elias Lönnrot") to collect Finnish and
Karelian folk poetry and arrange and publish them as the
_[Kalevala](/wiki/Kalevala "Kalevala")_ , the Finnish [national
epic](/wiki/National_epic "National epic"). The era saw a rise of poets and
novelists who wrote in Finnish, notably [Aleksis Kivi](/wiki/Aleksis_Kivi
"Aleksis Kivi") and [Eino Leino](/wiki/Eino_Leino "Eino Leino"). Many writers
of the national awakening wrote in Swedish, such as the national poet [Johan
Ludvig Runeberg](/wiki/Johan_Ludvig_Runeberg "Johan Ludvig Runeberg") and
[Zachris Topelius](/wiki/Zachris_Topelius "Zachris Topelius").

After Finland became independent, there was a rise of [modernist
writers](/wiki/Modernist_literature "Modernist literature"), most famously the
Finnish-speaking [Mika Waltari](/wiki/Mika_Waltari "Mika Waltari") and
Swedish-speaking [Edith Södergran](/wiki/Edith_S%C3%B6dergran "Edith
Södergran"). [Frans Eemil Sillanpää](/wiki/Frans_Eemil_Sillanp%C3%A4%C3%A4
"Frans Eemil Sillanpää") was awarded the [Nobel Prize in
Literature](/wiki/Nobel_Prize_in_Literature "Nobel Prize in Literature") in
1939. World War II prompted a return to more national interests in comparison
to a more international line of thought, characterized by [Väinö
Linna](/wiki/V%C3%A4in%C3%B6_Linna "Väinö Linna"). Besides Kalevala and
Waltari, the Swedish-speaking [Tove Jansson](/wiki/Tove_Jansson "Tove
Jansson") is the most translated Finnish writer. Popular modern writers
include [Arto Paasilinna](/wiki/Arto_Paasilinna "Arto Paasilinna"), [Ilkka
Remes](/wiki/Ilkka_Remes "Ilkka Remes"), [Kari
Hotakainen](/wiki/Kari_Hotakainen "Kari Hotakainen"), [Sofi
Oksanen](/wiki/Sofi_Oksanen "Sofi Oksanen"), and [Jari Tervo](/wiki/Jari_Tervo
"Jari Tervo"), while the best novel is annually awarded the prestigious
[Finlandia Prize](/wiki/Finlandia_Prize "Finlandia Prize").

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/b/b8/Sammon_puolustus.jpg/220px-
Sammon_puolustus.jpg)](/wiki/File:Sammon_puolustus.jpg)

[](/wiki/File:Sammon_puolustus.jpg "Enlarge")

[Akseli Gallen-Kallela](/wiki/Akseli_Gallen-Kallela "Akseli Gallen-Kallela"),
_[The Defense of the Sampo](/wiki/The_Defense_of_the_Sampo "The Defense of the
Sampo")_ , 1896, [Turku Art Museum](/wiki/Turku_Art_Museum "Turku Art
Museum").

### Visual arts, design, and
architecture[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Finland&action=edit&section=38 "Edit
section: Visual arts, design, and architecture")]

See also: [Architecture of Finland](/wiki/Architecture_of_Finland
"Architecture of Finland") and [Art in Finland](/wiki/Art_in_Finland "Art in
Finland")

The visual arts in Finland started to form their individual characteristics in
the 19th century, when Romantic nationalism was rising in autonomic Finland.
The best known of Finnish painters, [Akseli Gallen-
Kallela](/wiki/Akseli_Gallen-Kallela "Akseli Gallen-Kallela"), started
painting in a naturalist style, but moved to national romanticism. Finland's
best-known sculptor of the twentieth century was [Wäinö
Aaltonen](/wiki/W%C3%A4in%C3%B6_Aaltonen "Wäinö Aaltonen"), remembered for his
monumental [busts](/wiki/Bust_\(sculpture\) "Bust \(sculpture\)") and
sculptures. Finns have made major contributions to
[handicrafts](/wiki/Handicraft "Handicraft") and [industrial
design](/wiki/Industrial_design "Industrial design"): among the
internationally renowned figures are [Timo Sarpaneva](/wiki/Timo_Sarpaneva
"Timo Sarpaneva"), [Tapio Wirkkala](/wiki/Tapio_Wirkkala "Tapio Wirkkala") and
[Ilmari Tapiovaara](/wiki/Ilmari_Tapiovaara "Ilmari Tapiovaara"). Finnish
architecture is famous around the world, and has contributed significantly to
several styles internationally, such as [Jugendstil](/wiki/Jugendstil
"Jugendstil") (or [Art Nouveau](/wiki/Art_Nouveau "Art Nouveau")), [Nordic
Classicism](/wiki/Nordic_Classicism "Nordic Classicism") and
[Functionalism](/wiki/Functionalism_\(architecture\) "Functionalism
\(architecture\)"). Among the top twentieth-century Finnish architects to gain
international recognition are [Eliel Saarinen](/wiki/Eliel_Saarinen "Eliel
Saarinen") and his son [Eero Saarinen](/wiki/Eero_Saarinen "Eero Saarinen").
Architect [Alvar Aalto](/wiki/Alvar_Aalto "Alvar Aalto") is regarded as among
the most important twentieth-century designers in the world;[172] he helped
bring [functionalist architecture](/wiki/Functionalism_\(architecture\)
"Functionalism \(architecture\)") to Finland, but soon was a pioneer in its
development towards an organic style.[173] Aalto is also famous for his work
in furniture, lamps, textiles and [glassware](/wiki/Glassware "Glassware"),
which were usually incorporated into his buildings.

### Music[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Finland&action=edit&section=39 "Edit
section: Music")]

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/2/2b/Jean_Sibelius%2C_1913.jpg/170px-
Jean_Sibelius%2C_1913.jpg)](/wiki/File:Jean_Sibelius,_1913.jpg)

[](/wiki/File:Jean_Sibelius,_1913.jpg "Enlarge")

The Finnish composer [Jean Sibelius](/wiki/Jean_Sibelius "Jean Sibelius")
(1865–1957), a significant figure in the history of [classical
music](/wiki/European_classical_music "European classical music").

Main articles: [Music of Finland](/wiki/Music_of_Finland "Music of Finland"),
[Rock music in Finland](/wiki/Rock_music_in_Finland "Rock music in Finland"),
and [Sami music](/wiki/Sami_music "Sami music")

#### Classical[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Finland&action=edit&section=40 "Edit
section: Classical")]

Much of Finland's classical music is influenced by traditional Karelian
melodies and lyrics, as comprised in the _[Kalevala](/wiki/Kalevala
"Kalevala")_. Karelian culture is perceived as the purest expression of the
[Finnic](/wiki/Finnic_peoples "Finnic peoples") myths and beliefs, less
influenced by [Germanic](/wiki/Germanic_peoples "Germanic peoples") influence
than the [Nordic folk dance music](/wiki/Nordic_folk_dance_music "Nordic folk
dance music") that largely replaced the kalevaic tradition. Finnish [folk
music](/wiki/Folk_music "Folk music") has undergone a [roots
revival](/wiki/Roots_revival "Roots revival") in recent decades, and has
become a part of [popular music](/wiki/Popular_music "Popular music").

The people of northern Finland, Sweden, and Norway, the
[Sami](/wiki/Sami_people "Sami people"), are known primarily for highly
spiritual songs called [joik](/wiki/Joik "Joik"). The same word sometimes
refers to [lavlu](/wiki/Lavlu "Lavlu") or vuelie songs, though this is
technically incorrect.

The first Finnish opera was written by the German-born composer [Fredrik
Pacius](/wiki/Fredrik_Pacius "Fredrik Pacius") in 1852. Pacius also wrote the
music to the poem [_Maamme/Vårt land_ (Our Country)](/wiki/Maamme "Maamme"),
Finland's [national anthem](/wiki/National_anthem "National anthem"). In the
1890s Finnish nationalism based on the _Kalevala_ spread, and [Jean
Sibelius](/wiki/Jean_Sibelius "Jean Sibelius") became famous for his vocal
symphony _[Kullervo](/wiki/Kullervo_\(Sibelius\) "Kullervo \(Sibelius\)")_. He
soon received a grant to study _runo singers_ in Karelia and continued his
rise as the first prominent Finnish musician. In 1899 he composed
_[Finlandia](/wiki/Finlandia "Finlandia")_ , which played its important role
in Finland gaining independence. He remains one of Finland's most popular
national figures and is a symbol of the nation.

Today, Finland has a very lively classical music scene and many of Finland's
important [composers](/wiki/List_of_Finnish_composers "List of Finnish
composers") are still alive, such as [Magnus Lindberg](/wiki/Magnus_Lindberg
"Magnus Lindberg"), [Kaija Saariaho](/wiki/Kaija_Saariaho "Kaija Saariaho"),
[Kalevi Aho](/wiki/Kalevi_Aho "Kalevi Aho"), and [Aulis
Sallinen](/wiki/Aulis_Sallinen "Aulis Sallinen"). The composers are
accompanied by a large number of great conductors such as [Esa-Pekka
Salonen](/wiki/Esa-Pekka_Salonen "Esa-Pekka Salonen"), [Osmo
Vänskä](/wiki/Osmo_V%C3%A4nsk%C3%A4 "Osmo Vänskä"), [Jukka-Pekka
Saraste](/wiki/Jukka-Pekka_Saraste "Jukka-Pekka Saraste"), and [Leif
Segerstam](/wiki/Leif_Segerstam "Leif Segerstam"). Some of the internationally
acclaimed Finnish classical musicians are [Karita
Mattila](/wiki/Karita_Mattila "Karita Mattila"), [Soile
Isokoski](/wiki/Soile_Isokoski "Soile Isokoski"), [Pekka
Kuusisto](/wiki/Pekka_Kuusisto "Pekka Kuusisto"), [Olli
Mustonen](/wiki/Olli_Mustonen "Olli Mustonen"), and [Linda
Lampenius](/wiki/Linda_Brava "Linda Brava").

#### Modern[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Finland&action=edit&section=41 "Edit
section: Modern")]

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/e/e3/Apocalyptica1.jpg/170px-
Apocalyptica1.jpg)](/wiki/File:Apocalyptica1.jpg)

[](/wiki/File:Apocalyptica1.jpg "Enlarge")

[Perttu Kivilaakso](/wiki/Perttu_Kivilaakso "Perttu Kivilaakso") of
[Apocalyptica](/wiki/Apocalyptica "Apocalyptica").

_Iskelmä_ (coined directly from the German word _[Schlager](/wiki/Schlager
"Schlager")_ , meaning "hit") is a traditional Finnish word for a light
popular song. Finnish popular music also includes various kinds of [dance
music](/wiki/Dance_music "Dance music"); [tango](/wiki/Tango_music "Tango
music"), a style of [Argentine music](/wiki/Music_of_Argentina "Music of
Argentina"), is also popular. The light music in Swedish-speaking areas has
more influences from Sweden. Modern Finnish popular music includes a number of
prominent rock bands, [jazz](/wiki/Jazz "Jazz") musicians, [hip
hop](/wiki/Hip_hop "Hip hop") performers, dance music acts, etc.[_[citation
needed](/wiki/Wikipedia:Citation_needed "Wikipedia:Citation needed")_]

During the early 1960s, the first significant wave of Finnish rock groups
emerged, playing [instrumental rock](/wiki/Instrumental_rock "Instrumental
rock") inspired by groups such as [The Shadows](/wiki/The_Shadows "The
Shadows"). Around 1964, [Beatlemania](/wiki/Beatlemania "Beatlemania") arrived
in Finland, resulting in further development of the local rock scene. During
the late 1960s and 1970s, Finnish rock musicians increasingly wrote their own
music instead of translating international hits into Finnish. During the
decade, some [progressive rock](/wiki/Progressive_rock "Progressive rock")
groups such as [Tasavallan Presidentti](/wiki/Tasavallan_Presidentti
"Tasavallan Presidentti") and [Wigwam](/wiki/Wigwam_\(Finnish_band\) "Wigwam
\(Finnish band\)") gained respect abroad but failed to make a commercial
breakthrough outside Finland. This was also the fate of the [rock and
roll](/wiki/Rock_and_roll "Rock and roll") group [Hurriganes](/wiki/Hurriganes
"Hurriganes"). The Finnish punk scene produced some internationally
acknowledged names including [Terveet Kädet](/wiki/Terveet_K%C3%A4det "Terveet
Kädet") in the 1980s. [Hanoi Rocks](/wiki/Hanoi_Rocks "Hanoi Rocks") was a
pioneering 1980s [glam rock](/wiki/Glam_rock "Glam rock") act that inspired
the American [hard rock](/wiki/Hard_rock "Hard rock") group [Guns N'
Roses](/wiki/Guns_N%27_Roses "Guns N' Roses"), among others.[174]

Many Finnish metal bands have gained international recognition.
[HIM](/wiki/HIM_\(Finnish_band\) "HIM \(Finnish band\)") and
[Nightwish](/wiki/Nightwish "Nightwish") are some of Finland's most
internationally known bands. HIM's 2005 album _Dark Light_ [went
gold](/wiki/Music_recording_sales_certification "Music recording sales
certification") in the United States. [Apocalyptica](/wiki/Apocalyptica
"Apocalyptica") are an internationally famous Finnish group who are most
renowned for mixing strings-led classical music with classic heavy metal.
Other well-known metal bands are [Amorphis](/wiki/Amorphis "Amorphis"),
[Children of Bodom](/wiki/Children_of_Bodom "Children of Bodom"), [Impaled
Nazarene](/wiki/Impaled_Nazarene "Impaled Nazarene"),
[Korpiklaani](/wiki/Korpiklaani "Korpiklaani"), [Sentenced](/wiki/Sentenced
"Sentenced"), [Sonata Arctica](/wiki/Sonata_Arctica "Sonata Arctica"),
[Stratovarius](/wiki/Stratovarius "Stratovarius"), [Turisas](/wiki/Turisas
"Turisas"), [Finntroll](/wiki/Finntroll "Finntroll"),
[Ensiferum](/wiki/Ensiferum "Ensiferum"), [Insomnium](/wiki/Insomnium
"Insomnium"), [Moonsorrow](/wiki/Moonsorrow "Moonsorrow"),
[Wintersun](/wiki/Wintersun "Wintersun"), [Poets of the
Fall](/wiki/Poets_of_the_Fall "Poets of the Fall"), and
[Waltari](/wiki/Waltari "Waltari").[_[citation
needed](/wiki/Wikipedia:Citation_needed "Wikipedia:Citation needed")_]

After Finnish hard rock/heavy metal band [Lordi](/wiki/Lordi "Lordi") won the
[2006 Eurovision Song Contest](/wiki/Eurovision_Song_Contest_2006 "Eurovision
Song Contest 2006"), Finland hosted the competition [in
2007](/wiki/Eurovision_Song_Contest_2007 "Eurovision Song Contest 2007").[175]

### Cinema and
television[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Finland&action=edit&section=42 "Edit
section: Cinema and television")]

Main articles: [Cinema of Finland](/wiki/Cinema_of_Finland "Cinema of
Finland") and [Television in Finland](/wiki/Television_in_Finland "Television
in Finland")

See also: [Lists of Finnish films](/wiki/Lists_of_Finnish_films "Lists of
Finnish films")

In the film industry, notable directors include [Aki
Kaurismäki](/wiki/Aki_Kaurism%C3%A4ki "Aki Kaurismäki"), [Mauritz
Stiller](/wiki/Mauritz_Stiller "Mauritz Stiller"), [Spede
Pasanen](/wiki/Spede_Pasanen "Spede Pasanen"), and Hollywood film director and
producer [Renny Harlin](/wiki/Renny_Harlin "Renny Harlin"). Around twelve
feature films are made each year.[176]

Finland's most internationally successful TV shows are the backpacking travel
documentary series _[Madventures](/wiki/Madventures "Madventures")_ and the
reality TV show _[The Dudesons](/wiki/The_Dudesons "The Dudesons")_ , about
four childhood friends who perform stunts and play pranks on each other (in
similar vein to the American TV show _[Jackass](/wiki/Jackass_\(TV_series\)
"Jackass \(TV series\)")_).

### Media and
communications[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Finland&action=edit&section=43 "Edit
section: Media and communications")]

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/6/69/Linus_Torvalds.jpeg/170px-
Linus_Torvalds.jpeg)](/wiki/File:Linus_Torvalds.jpeg)

[](/wiki/File:Linus_Torvalds.jpeg "Enlarge")

[Linus Torvalds](/wiki/Linus_Torvalds "Linus Torvalds"), the Finnish [software
engineer](/wiki/Software_engineering "Software engineering") best known for
creating the popular [open-source](/wiki/Open_source "Open source")
[kernel](/wiki/Kernel_\(operating_system\) "Kernel \(operating system\)")
[Linux](/wiki/Linux "Linux").

See also: [Telecommunications in Finland](/wiki/Telecommunications_in_Finland
"Telecommunications in Finland") and [List of newspapers in
Finland](/wiki/List_of_newspapers_in_Finland "List of newspapers in Finland")

Thanks to its emphasis on transparency and equal rights, Finland's press has
been rated the freest in the world.[177]

Today, there are around 200 newspapers, 320 popular magazines, 2,100
professional magazines, 67 commercial radio stations, three [digital
radio](/wiki/Digital_radio "Digital radio") channels and one nationwide and
five national [public service radio channels](/wiki/Public_broadcasting
"Public broadcasting").

Each year, around 12,000 book titles are published and 12 million records are
sold.[176]

[Sanoma](/wiki/Sanoma "Sanoma") publishes the newspaper _[Helsingin
Sanomat](/wiki/Helsingin_Sanomat "Helsingin Sanomat")_ (its circulation of
412,000[178] making it the largest), the
[tabloid](/wiki/Tabloid_\(newspaper_format\) "Tabloid \(newspaper format\)")
_[Ilta-Sanomat](/wiki/Ilta-Sanomat "Ilta-Sanomat")_ , the commerce-oriented
_[Taloussanomat](/wiki/Taloussanomat "Taloussanomat")_ and the television
channel [Nelonen](/wiki/Nelonen "Nelonen"). The other major publisher [Alma
Media](/wiki/Alma_Media "Alma Media") publishes over thirty magazines,
including the newspaper _[Aamulehti](/wiki/Aamulehti "Aamulehti")_ , tabloid
_[Iltalehti](/wiki/Iltalehti "Iltalehti")_ and commerce-oriented
_[Kauppalehti](/wiki/Kauppalehti "Kauppalehti")_. Worldwide, Finns, along with
other Nordic peoples and the Japanese, spend the most time reading
newspapers.[179]

Yle, the Finnish Broadcasting Company, operates five television channels and
thirteen radio channels in both national languages. Yle is funded through a
mandatory television license and fees for private broadcasters. All TV
channels are broadcast [digitally](/wiki/Digital_television "Digital
television"), both terrestrially and on cable. The commercial television
channel [MTV3](/wiki/MTV3 "MTV3") and commercial radio channel [Radio
Nova](/wiki/Radio_Nova_\(Finland\) "Radio Nova \(Finland\)") are owned by
Nordic Broadcasting ([Bonnier](/wiki/Bonnier_Group "Bonnier Group") and
Proventus Industrier).

In regards to telecommunication infrastructure, Finland is the highest ranked
country in the World Economic Forum's Network Readiness Index (NRI) – an
indicator for determining the development level of a country's information and
communication technologies. Finland ranked 1st overall in the 2014 NRI
ranking, unchanged from the year before.[180] This is shown in its penetration
throughout the country's population. Around 79% of the population use the
Internet.[181] Finland had around 1.52 million broadband Internet connections
by the end of June 2007 or around 287 per 1,000 inhabitants.[182] All Finnish
schools and public libraries have Internet connections and computers and most
residents have a mobile phone. [Value-added services](/wiki/Value-
added_service "Value-added service") are rare.[183] In October 2009, Finland's
Ministry of Transport and Communications committed to ensuring that every
person in Finland would be able to access the Internet at a minimum speed of
one [megabit-per-second](/wiki/Data_rate_units#Decimal_multiples_of_bits "Data
rate units") beginning July 2010.[184]

### Cuisine[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Finland&action=edit&section=44 "Edit
section: Cuisine")]

Main article: [Finnish cuisine](/wiki/Finnish_cuisine "Finnish cuisine")

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/7/78/Karjalanpiirakka-20060227.jpg/220px-
Karjalanpiirakka-20060227.jpg)](/wiki/File:Karjalanpiirakka-20060227.jpg)

[](/wiki/File:Karjalanpiirakka-20060227.jpg "Enlarge")

[Karelian pasty](/wiki/Karjalanpiirakat "Karjalanpiirakat")
(_karjalanpiirakka_) is a traditional Finnish dish made from a thin rye crust
with a filling of rice. Butter, often mixed with boiled egg (eggbutter or
munavoi), is spread over the hot pastries before eating.

Finnish cuisine is notable for generally combining traditional country fare
and _[haute cuisine](/wiki/Haute_cuisine "Haute cuisine")_ with contemporary
style cooking. [Fish](/wiki/Fish_\(food\) "Fish \(food\)") and meat play a
prominent role in traditional Finnish dishes from the western part of the
country, while the dishes from the eastern part have traditionally included
various vegetables and [mushrooms](/wiki/Edible_mushroom "Edible mushroom").
Refugees from Karelia contributed to foods in eastern Finland.

Finnish foods often use [wholemeal](/wiki/Wholemeal "Wholemeal") products
([rye](/wiki/Rye "Rye"), [barley](/wiki/Barley "Barley"), [oats](/wiki/Oat
"Oat")) and berries (such as [bilberries](/wiki/Bilberry "Bilberry"),
[lingonberries](/wiki/Lingonberry "Lingonberry"),
[cloudberries](/wiki/Cloudberry "Cloudberry"), and [sea
buckthorn](/wiki/Sea_buckthorn "Sea buckthorn")). Milk and its derivatives
like [buttermilk](/wiki/Buttermilk "Buttermilk") are commonly used as food,
drink, or in various recipes. Various [turnips](/wiki/Turnip "Turnip") were
common in traditional cooking, but were replaced with the potato after its
introduction in the 18th century.

According to the statistics, red meat consumption has risen, but still Finns
eat less beef than many other nations, and more fish and poultry. This is
mainly because of the high cost of meat in Finland.

Finland is the top world consumer of coffee per capita.[185]

### Public holidays[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Finland&action=edit&section=45
"Edit section: Public holidays")]

Main articles: [Public holidays in Finland](/wiki/Public_holidays_in_Finland
"Public holidays in Finland") and [Flag days in
Finland](/wiki/Flag_days_in_Finland "Flag days in Finland")

All official holidays in Finland are established by Acts of Parliament.
Christian holidays include Christmas, New Year's Day,
[Epiphany](/wiki/Epiphany_\(Christian\) "Epiphany \(Christian\)"), Easter,
[Ascension Day](/wiki/Ascension_of_Jesus_Christ "Ascension of Jesus Christ"),
[Pentecost](/wiki/Pentecost "Pentecost"), [Midsummer](/wiki/Midsummer
"Midsummer") Day (St. John's Day), and [All Saints'
Day](/wiki/All_Saints%27_Day "All Saints' Day"), while secular holidays
include May Day, [Independence Day](/wiki/Independence_Day_of_Finland
"Independence Day of Finland"), New Year's Day, and Midsummer. Christmas is
the most extensively celebrated, and at least 24 to 26 December is taken as a
holiday.

### Sports[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Finland&action=edit&section=46 "Edit
section: Sports")]

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/7/70/Finlandbronzecelebration2010WinterOlympics.jpg/220px-
Finlandbronzecelebration2010WinterOlympics.jpg)](/wiki/File:Finlandbronzecelebration2010WinterOlympics.jpg)

[](/wiki/File:Finlandbronzecelebration2010WinterOlympics.jpg "Enlarge")

Finland's [men's national ice hockey
team](/wiki/Finland_men%27s_national_ice_hockey_team "Finland men's national
ice hockey team") is [ranked](/wiki/IIHF_World_Ranking "IIHF World Ranking")
as one of the best in the world. The team has won two world championship
titles (in 1995 & 2011) and six Olympic medals.

Main article: [Sport in Finland](/wiki/Sport_in_Finland "Sport in Finland")

Various sporting events are popular in Finland.
[Pesäpallo](/wiki/Pes%C3%A4pallo "Pesäpallo"), resembling baseball, is the
national sport of Finland, although the most popular sports in terms of
spectators is [ice hockey](/wiki/Ice_hockey "Ice hockey"). [Ice Hockey World
Championships 2016](/wiki/2016_IIHF_World_Championship "2016 IIHF World
Championship") final Finland-Canada, 69% Finnish people watched that game on
TV.[186] Other popular sports include [athletics](/wiki/Track_and_field "Track
and field"), [cross-country skiing](/wiki/Cross-country_skiing "Cross-country
skiing"), [ski jumping](/wiki/Ski_jumping "Ski jumping"),
[football](/wiki/Association_football "Association football") and
[basketball](/wiki/Basketball "Basketball").[187] While ice hockey is the most
popular sports when it comes to attendance at games, [association
football](/wiki/Association_football "Association football") is the most
played team sport in terms of the amount of players in the country and is also
the most appreciated sports in Finland.[188][189]

In terms of medals and gold medals won per capita, Finland is the best
performing country in Olympic history.[190] Finland first participated as a
nation in its own right at the [Olympic Games](/wiki/Olympic_Games "Olympic
Games") in 1908, while still an autonomous [Grand
Duchy](/wiki/Grand_Duchy_of_Finland "Grand Duchy of Finland") within the
[Russian Empire](/wiki/Russian_Empire "Russian Empire"). At the [1912 Summer
Olympics](/wiki/1912_Summer_Olympics "1912 Summer Olympics"), great pride was
taken in the three gold medals won by the original "[Flying
Finn](/wiki/Flying_Finn "Flying Finn")" [Hannes
Kolehmainen](/wiki/Hannes_Kolehmainen "Hannes Kolehmainen").

Finland was one of the most successful countries at the Olympic Games before
[World War II](/wiki/World_War_II "World War II"). At the [1924 Summer
Olympics](/wiki/1924_Summer_Olympics "1924 Summer Olympics"), Finland, a
nation then of only 3.2 million people, came second in the medal count. In the
1920s and 1930s, Finnish long-distance runners dominated the Olympics, with
[Paavo Nurmi](/wiki/Paavo_Nurmi "Paavo Nurmi") winning a total of nine Olympic
gold medals between 1920 and 1928 and setting 22 official world records
between 1921 and 1931. Nurmi is often considered the greatest Finnish
sportsman and one of the greatest athletes of all time.

For over 100 years, Finnish male and female athletes have consistently
excelled at the [javelin throw](/wiki/Javelin_throw "Javelin throw"). The
event has brought Finland nine Olympic gold medals, five world championships,
five European championships, and 24 world records.

In addition to Kolehmainen and Nurmi, some of Finland's most internationally
well-known and successful sportspeople are long-distance runners [Ville
Ritola](/wiki/Ville_Ritola "Ville Ritola") and [Lasse
Virén](/wiki/Lasse_Vir%C3%A9n "Lasse Virén"); ski-jumpers [Matti
Nykänen](/wiki/Matti_Nyk%C3%A4nen "Matti Nykänen") and [Janne
Ahonen](/wiki/Janne_Ahonen "Janne Ahonen"); cross-country skiers [Veikko
Hakulinen](/wiki/Veikko_Hakulinen "Veikko Hakulinen"), [Eero
Mäntyranta](/wiki/Eero_M%C3%A4ntyranta "Eero Mäntyranta"), [Marja-Liisa
Kirvesniemi](/wiki/Marja-Liisa_Kirvesniemi "Marja-Liisa Kirvesniemi") and
[Mika Myllylä](/wiki/Mika_Myllyl%C3%A4 "Mika Myllylä"); rower [Pertti
Karppinen](/wiki/Pertti_Karppinen "Pertti Karppinen"); gymnast [Heikki
Savolainen](/wiki/Heikki_Savolainen_\(gymnast\) "Heikki Savolainen
\(gymnast\)"); professional skateboarder [Arto Saari](/wiki/Arto_Saari "Arto
Saari"); ice hockey players [Kimmo Timonen](/wiki/Kimmo_Timonen "Kimmo
Timonen"), [Jari Kurri](/wiki/Jari_Kurri "Jari Kurri"), [Teemu
Selänne](/wiki/Teemu_Sel%C3%A4nne "Teemu Selänne"), and [Saku
Koivu](/wiki/Saku_Koivu "Saku Koivu"); football players [Jari
Litmanen](/wiki/Jari_Litmanen "Jari Litmanen") and [Sami
Hyypiä](/wiki/Sami_Hyypi%C3%A4 "Sami Hyypiä"); basketball player [Hanno
Möttölä](/wiki/Hanno_M%C3%B6tt%C3%B6l%C3%A4 "Hanno Möttölä"); alpine skiers
[Kalle Palander](/wiki/Kalle_Palander "Kalle Palander") and [Tanja
Poutiainen](/wiki/Tanja_Poutiainen "Tanja Poutiainen"); Formula One world
champions [Keke Rosberg](/wiki/Keke_Rosberg "Keke Rosberg"), [Mika
Häkkinen](/wiki/Mika_H%C3%A4kkinen "Mika Häkkinen") and [Kimi
Räikkönen](/wiki/Kimi_R%C3%A4ikk%C3%B6nen "Kimi Räikkönen"); four-time World
Rally champions [Juha Kankkunen](/wiki/Juha_Kankkunen "Juha Kankkunen") and
[Tommi Mäkinen](/wiki/Tommi_M%C3%A4kinen "Tommi Mäkinen"); and 13-time World
[Enduro](/wiki/Enduro "Enduro") Champion [Juha Salminen](/wiki/Juha_Salminen
"Juha Salminen"), seven-time champion [Kari Tiainen](/wiki/Kari_Tiainen "Kari
Tiainen"), and the five-time champions [Mika Ahola](/wiki/Mika_Ahola "Mika
Ahola"), biathlete [Kaisa Mäkäräinen](/wiki/Kaisa_M%C3%A4k%C3%A4r%C3%A4inen
"Kaisa Mäkäräinen") and [Samuli Aro](/wiki/Samuli_Aro "Samuli Aro"). Finland
is also one of the most successful nations in [bandy](/wiki/Bandy "Bandy"),
being the only nation beside Russia and Sweden to win a [Bandy World
Championship](/wiki/Bandy_World_Championship "Bandy World Championship").

The [1952 Summer Olympics](/wiki/1952_Summer_Olympics "1952 Summer Olympics")
were held in Helsinki. Other notable sporting events held in Finland include
the [1983](/wiki/1983_World_Championships_in_Athletics "1983 World
Championships in Athletics") and [2005 World Championships in
Athletics](/wiki/2005_World_Championships_in_Athletics "2005 World
Championships in Athletics").

Finland also has a notable history in [figure skating](/wiki/Figure_skating
"Figure skating"). Finnish skaters have won 8 world championships and 13
junior world cups in synchronized skating, and Finland is considered one of
the best countries at the sport.

Some of the most popular recreational sports and activities include
[floorball](/wiki/Floorball "Floorball"), [Nordic
walking](/wiki/Nordic_walking "Nordic walking"), running, cycling, and skiing
([alpine skiing](/wiki/Alpine_skiing "Alpine skiing"), [cross-country
skiing](/wiki/Cross-country_skiing "Cross-country skiing"), and [ski
jumping](/wiki/Ski_jumping "Ski jumping")). Floorball, in terms of registered
players, occupies third place after football and ice hockey. According to the
Finnish Floorball Federation, floorball is the most popular school, youth,
club and workplace sport.[191] As of 2016, the total number of licensed
players reaches 57,400.[192]

Especially since the [2014 FIBA Basketball World
Cup](/wiki/2014_FIBA_Basketball_World_Cup "2014 FIBA Basketball World Cup"),
[Finland's national basketball team](/wiki/Finland_national_basketball_team
"Finland national basketball team") has received widespread public attention.
More than 8,000 Finns travelled to Spain to support their team. Overall, they
chartered more than 40 airplanes.[193]

  1. ^ Jump up to: _**a**_ _**b**_ Formerly a semi-presidential republic, it is now a parliamentary republic according to David Arter, First Chair of Politics at Aberdeen University. In his "Scandinavian Politics Today" (Manchester University Press, revised 2008 [ISBN](/wiki/International_Standard_Book_Number_\(identifier\) "International Standard Book Number \(identifier\)") [9780719078538](/wiki/Special:BookSources/9780719078538 "Special:BookSources/9780719078538")), he quotes Nousiainen, Jaakko (June 2001). ["From semi-presidentialism to parliamentary government: political and constitutional developments in Finland"](https://dx.doi.org/10.1111/1467-9477.00048). _[Scandinavian Political Studies](/wiki/Scandinavian_Political_Studies "Scandinavian Political Studies")_. [Wiley](/wiki/Wiley-Blackwell "Wiley-Blackwell"). **24** (2): 95–109. [doi](/wiki/Digital_object_identifier "Digital object identifier"):[10.1111/1467-9477.00048](//doi.org/10.1111%2F1467-9477.00048). as follows: "There are hardly any grounds for the epithet 'semi-presidential'." Arter's own conclusions are only slightly more nuanced: "The adoption of a new constitution on 1 March 2000 meant that Finland was no longer a case of semi-presidential government other than in the minimalist sense of a situation where a popularly elected fixed-term president exists alongside a prime minister and cabinet who are responsible to parliament (Elgie 2004: 317)". According to the Finnish Constitution, the president has no possibility to rule the government without the ministerial approval, and does not have the power to dissolve the parliament under his or her own desire. Finland is actually represented by its prime minister, and not by its president, in the Council of the Heads of State and Government of the European Union. The 2012 constitutional amendments reduced the powers of the president even further.
